It's a cute market, the people seem friendly enough and there are definitely a lot of tempting looking items like specialty desserts and prepacked cheese spreads and dips. If you like upscale chocolate like Rechiutti they have it.

By the way, Canyon Market is NOT BiRite Market. BiRite Market is amazing and has much better sandwiches. Sorry, Canyon, it's the truth.
author: E L.

description:
Canyon Market is a great place to shop. Yes, it's a little pricey, but it's a such a small store that I like to think all these items were hand picked for all of us. 

I love their deli counter, the sandwiches are so big. They have awesome side salads and the crab cakes are delicious. Ask them to heat them up a bit, definitely worth it. Perfect for any occasion. 

They have a great meat and cheese selection. Excellent Salad bar. Extensive juice and beverage selection. The wines are priced from reasonable to pricey. Who can complain?

My favorite little thing that makes this neighborhood store a little friendlier: Their coffee card system is an index card box where you can keep your own card instead of losing it and finding a few later while cleaning out your purses. (Maybe that's just me)
author: Rebekah T.

description:
My husband and I have lived in Glen Park for a little over a year now. Canyon Market is a great place -- a neat hybrid of small and big. The prepared foods are generally very good, and the soups are super tasty. But I must relate a negative experience that, for better or for worse, caused us to stop shopping there for a few months.

We had bought two bunches of organic curly kale to use in our Kale and White Bean Soup. I am quite fastidious when washing leafy vegetables, and as I was washing the kale one leaf at a time, I discovered a slug. And then another. And another. And another. And another. I called my husband over and said that I had found not one, but FIVE slugs in the kale. He picked up a leaf and said, "Oh my god, don't look!" and this made me want to look, and I wish I hadn't, because it was a full-sized black beetle.

So we composted the kale and ordered pizza.

Fast forward to the next time we were at Canyon Market. We were unloading several items at the checkstand and I remembered the slugs and the beetle. So I mentioned this to the cashier, and he said, "Well, that's how you know it's organic." Really? My husband and I have been buying and cooking with organic vegetables for years, and we are not under the impression that "organic" and "pest-ridden" are the same thing. Organic doesn't mean that pests aren't controlled -- it mandates the ways in which pests are controlled.

Anyway, an occasional bug is not a big deal, and if I'd only found one slug in the kale, I would have removed it and moved on. But five slugs and a beetle -- that's over the top. A market, no matter what its size, should unhesitatingly stand behind the items it sells. If he had simply thanked us for the feedback and offered us a credit or something, we wouldn't have thought twice about it. But his response (not the slugs and the beetle!) caused us to stop shopping at Canyon Market for about three months, costing them many hundreds of dollars in lost sales, and for what? So they could save a dollar? 

We do most of our shopping at Whole Foods in Noe Valley. Say what you will about the big-boxiness of Whole Foods, but they stand behind their products 110%. They would never imply that you should expect to find five slugs and a beetle in your kale because it's organic. On the rare occasions when we've had a problem with something we've bought there, they have refunded or replaced it without hesitation. We do occasionally shop at Canyon Market now, but not as much as we used to.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This place is great. If you're like one of the many reviewers who think buying conventional produce and food full of high fructose corn syrup is a 'good deal' just because it costs less money, but then gives you diabetes and raises everyone else's healthcare costs, then this probably isn't going to be the store for you. There's a Safeway on Monterey Boulevard and another one up the hill off of Clipper across from Twin Peaks for all of your diabetes-inducing requirements. If you don't especially like cooking your own food and eat Chipotle 3 times a week and think it's the best burrito you've ever had, probably also not your kind of place.

Admittedly, the food here costs more than Safeway, but it doesn't cost any more than Whole Foods, and unlike Whole Foods it isn't a giant chain store; it's local to the neighborhood. In fact the only thing here that is actually a bit too expensive is the produce, but it's honestly very good produce and produce is still cheaper as a category than anything else, so it's not a big deal. If you really need cheap produce but don't want crap, I would go to the Alemany farmer's market down the road on the weekends.

More to the point, everything here is organic/fair trade/grass fed/hormone free/etc. etc. I agree that we shouldn't have to pay more for vegetables grown without nasty cancer-causing pesticides sprayed on them, meat that is humanely raised and slaughtered, and snacks that aren't full of diabetes-inducing high fructose corn syrup. What we call 'organic' today was just the way food was harvested 50 years ago; it wasn't a special category. Then again, food in this country is only as artificially cheap as it is because of Earl Butz' corn revolution in the 70's and the rise of agrobiz. So the 'extra' we pay for 'organic' food is actually just how much good ingredients probably should cost in the first place.

I personally like to cook my own food quite a lot, and I care very much about the quality of the things that go inside my body. Some people call me a 'foodie'; to me it's just normal. I don't mind investing extra money and time in meals that I and guests at my dinner table will remember for life. But that's just me. For a lot of Americans food is just a thing you cram in your mouth for a few minutes between doing other things. For me it's a way of living the good life without having to be a millionaire. The Italians call it 'la dolce vita'.

At this store I know I can meet all my grocery needs and not have to worry about buying anything cheap, bad for me, unethical or the like. Beer selection: one of the best in the city for a grocery store, although I do have to give first prize to the Noe Whole Foods. If I really want the best, I go to Healthy Spirits anyway. Canyon has Labyrinth regularly, which is not easy to find anywhere else, Old Rasputin, Einstok, 21st Amendment, Unibroue and an assortment of other craft beers. If you're really craving a Budweiser maybe go to the dive bar across the street instead; or one of the two liquor stores within half a block of the store. As far as other beverages, they have all of my favorites: Q soda drinks and Boylan, Stumptown iced coffee, Blue Bottle iced coffee. They have a decent assortment of wines, but I'm not a huge wine aficianado. I mostly buy cheap whites for cooking kick-ass meals. They have Straus everything, a wide variety of Bob's Red Mill products, Guittard baking chocolate in all varieties (even bulk), Casa Sanchez Totopos, house made merguez sausage, great bulk goods, decent coffee that I think is actually much better than Bello up the street, PG Tips, Oscar Wilde Cheddar, L'Amourette, Taza and many other fine chocolates (which you're supposed to suck on like hard candy a piece at a time, not hork down like 'muricans do), and one of the best BBQ chicken sandwiches I've ever had (which you are supposed to hork down). Also they have probably the best cheese section for a grocery store in the city. They also have fantastic breakfast sandwiches. If I worked downtown and had to take GP Bart to work I'd be in there every morning all like wut wut, where my toasted gruyere egg and cheese bagel, bia.. ma'am? They even sell the flaxseed oil I use to season my skillets and other iron cookware.

The staff is sometimes a little slow to help you just because, for a small store, they get a ton of business, and are usually pretty busy. However, they're some of the nicest, most dedicated grocery staff in town and I've never had anything but pleasant, helpful interactions with any of them. If you are a regular like I am, you will notice that some of the same people who were there when I moved into the neighborhood 4 years ago are still there, and still cheerful, which tells you something.

For the limited space they have, the selection is outstanding. And frankly, I like going to Avedano's, Mollie Stone's, Rainbow, Healthy Spirits, Nijiya and ordering the occasional thing online.
author: Steve S.

description: This family bussines have awesome products hard to find, great atmosphere and the best is Janet and Richard are there to help you out, thanks again i have a great experience!!!!!
author: Mario V.

description:
By far my favorite neighborhood market I've ever been to. After TWO times coming in to order the same sandwich, they remembered my name and let me know that they care about the regulars. What? Seriously?

When I worked making sandwiches back in the day I hated everybody. There are a couple neat places in glen park but the excellent food and awesome staff keep me coming back nearly everyday.
author: Nathan F.

description:
5 stars for location, selection, fresh produce and free samples. They have good deals on flowers and a selection of soaps that I've used for last minute gifts.

Minus 1 star for the coffee bar being ridiculously slow (I've waited 10 minutes on multiple occasions for a drink).

Minus 1 star for overpriced items. At least at Whole Foods you can find a selection of reasonably priced foods. Not here, yesterday I paid $11 for my salad from the salad bar.

In light of these complaints, I am addicted and keep coming back.  Canyon Market is a good addition to Glen Park and if they could improve the system at the coffee bar so I could reliably come in for a quick cup o' Joe, I would overlook the prices and change my review to 5 stars.
author: Johanna W.

description: I used to work near Glen Park, and would pick up often food at Canyon on the way. It has a great salad bar with a wide selection of salad dressings (my fave was the sesame!). They also have a coffee bar inside with good coffee and a selection of pastries and bagels/english muffins. I used to get english muffins with cream cheese, red onion, spinach, and tomatoes. The grocery food items aren't cheap though, from what I've seen, so I wouldn't recommend doing your regular grocery shopping there.
author: Jiselle L.

description: Great little neighborhood market.  large cheese selection, olive oils, organic meats and sustainably caught fish.  Also a large prepared food section.
author: john s.

description: First coming here I swore it was a Molly Stone. It has a nice balance of everything. Just the prices here aren't cheap and if someone was on the bigger side, they wouldn't fit in the isles. I am sure they are not handicap accessible.
author: M C.

description:
There's no Whole Foods nears us so we do all of our grocery shopping here.

The prices are what you'd expect from a specialty, organic grocery.  

Produce is always fresh, meat is the highest quality, and the staff is well informed of the products. 

Sometimes I wish they had just a little bit more selection (it's really a very small grocery), but it more than gets the job done.
author: Tay A.

description:
I love this place but not feeling to good about there food handling style.
This is what I wrote and hope they can adapt to a better practice.

To whom it may concern,
I am a local customer and was getting off of my shift at the hospital. I was looking forward to eating some of your baked goods in the cafe section. I noticed upon entering that the cafe employee was handling the baked goods with her bare hands and then getting more to stock in the front display. The manager was with her chatting. After she stocked the baked goods she would wipe her hands on her pants. 
I was concerned that the food I was about to eat was contaminated. 
I approached the manager (salt and pepper hair gentleman, 5'11" and mid 50's). I asked him to step aside to express my concern of the food handling.
The manager said it was safe because all Canyon Market employees wash their hands.
I then asked him if I go to the bathroom at this moment to wash my hands. I then can come out and sort through the pastries. He gave me no response.
I am submitting pages from the health department website and hope you may change your food handling practices.
author: Daniel G.

description:
After training a client in the Glen Park area and grabbing a coffee next door at Belo, I'm peeked my nose in this neighborhood market and immediately adored it. 

It has all you need from toothbrushes, wine, salad bar, deli, dark chocolate, flowers, cleaning products.  But the thing about it, is that it's all laid out so clean and organized in such an inviting way.  I didn't even have to buy anything, I simply appreciate the details and the tlc that I can tell went in to the store.

Next time I got a date with that awesome salad bar.
author: Desiree G.

description:
I'll start this review by expressing my discomfort/borderline hatred for large chain grocery stores. They are overwhelming and soulless. How many freaking choices in a toothpaste do I really need before I lose it? Why are there 25 cashiers with 3 open while there are 250 people in line? Big parking lots, too many cars. Zombies disguised as humans buying bulk paper towels. Bad lighting! Bad! 

Okay, now on to Canyon Market. When I recently moved from the Haight, I was super bummed to leave my beloved Haight Market. However, discovering Canyon Market, a short walk from my house, was such a relief. I have been shopping here now for about a month, and I know the people who work there, which is the way I like it. Nothing like shooting the sh*t with a familiar face twice a week while you spend loads of money on fine products such as homemade pizza crust (actually, this is very reasonable), hand crafted olive oil, fine bourbon, fresh, organic produce, all natural firewood and a really great selection of deli products. Their soup and salad bar is awesome. They have a small meat section. Oh- and I recently ordered my super fancy Thanksgiving turkey from them, I'll post an update after it is all said and done.
author: Natalie D.

description: I love the food selection, love to browse the isles to look at all the interesting products, love the staff, love the sandwiches, great coffee and breakfast sandwiches, stellar produce section, and delicious things in little containers to take home and feast on, great selection of chocolates - and most of all, I just love going into the store!  Such a welcoming place.
author: Susan P.

description:
A very expensive neighborhood market, but you're kind of paying for the variety of items they offer and the atmosphere. In short, it's a cute supermarket. I mean, they had decorations and an accordion player over the holidays strolling through the store ! You can't get that at Safeway.

In return, you pay 3x more than you normally would at any other supermarket. $6 dollars for a bottle of Martinelli's sparkling cider? No thanks. 

All in all, I like to stop by sometimes if I'm nearby to treat myself to a small dessert or some flowers.
author: Patricia Q.

description: Really good hot bar, fresh salsas, and the desserts are dangerous. A bit overpriced to be a one stop shop for groceries, but it's a cute spot with some delicious and unique options.
author: Kel L.

description:
My experience here is a delightful, riveting, and an often-climactic battle between my greater conscience and my financially flippant mannerisms.

The sandwiches are, dear, delightful. The carnitas sandwich and proscuitto with pickle are the only ones I have tried, and I am still boring my friends with poetic descriptions of the pickles. The fresh gardenias caressing the olfactory nerves upon entering this food mecca beckon me to take one home. And I do, even though it's totally silly.

This psychological battle is riveting. It's so expensive. But the food is so good, the samples are abundant, the product is displayed wonderfully. The selection is impeccable. And yet, I check my balance before purchasing.

And the climax - often when I eat my sandwich looking to Glen Canyon while listening in on a conversation outside - is as sensual as it is sequentially, as I often bike here from school seeking a retreat into the divinity of Glen Park.
author: Peter H.

description: Being new to town and living in Glen Park I figured I'd check out this market. Purchased premade options twice, and both times have not gone so well. The first time I purchased a Sesame Noodle Salad and upon opening it at home I found mold growing. Returned the item for cash credit with no issues. Stopped by again today and grabbed a couple calzones, one was marked as Tomato and Cheese. Once I cooked and took a bite, I realized it was actually Indian Vegetable or Somosa instead. Tasted good, but not what I was expecting or was in the mood for.
author: Jeffrey R.

description: I live closely and shop at Canyon Market a lot. Although I don't do my usual grocery shopping here, I drop by often for their soups, sandwiches, empanadas and desserts. Their lamb and veggie soup is my favorite here. Apart from their products, they have great service as well. Very friendly and helpful staff.
author: Pursarth T.

description: I don't think I can say enough wonderful things about this lovely market! We were in town staying with friends and I think we visited the market 6 times over the 4 days we were there. We would just stroll in for a muffin in the morning or grabbing sandwiches and the like from the deli. Their cheese selection is incredible! Fresh veggies & fruits galore! All the while carrying a nice selection of wine which we enjoyed as well! All around love, I wish I had this place down the street from my house!
author: Mindy N.

description:
We ordered food from their deli to be catered for a holiday party.  In the early evening one day before our party, our toddler came down with a runny nose and was running very warm-- Everyone on staff was super nice when I told them about my predicament, which I SO appreciated.  I spoke with Julie Scott at the deli and she was very understanding and said she'd work with me to cancel the order if I had to cancel our holiday party in case our kid developed a raging fever.

Fast foward to the next day-- our daughter amazingly recovered and the party went forth and they delivered delicious, tasty food that everyone (even the horde of children!) raved about (especially the chicken macaroni salad and the cheese and fruit plate).

We heart Canyon Market.
author: Corii L.

description:
One time I treated myself to $10 apricot jam. Best jam ever. 

And another time I treated myself to 4oz. of boar salami ($16). 

CM also offers yogurt starter and dried lavender. 

I think I tried mimolette for the first time here. I can't remember... the cheese wall is always fun to sniff and read. 

I also like to shop here because it makes me feel fancy.
author: Jacquee P.

description: Great grocery store. Getting the grilled cheese sandwich today. Nice size and at a reasonable price. Can't really mess up a grilled cheese sandwich and love that they add different types of cheese. Just picture a smaller, neighborhood type of whole foods.
author: JJ S.

description: Kudos to the store owner for making a bad situation right.  I have been a customer since they opened and will continue to shop there in the future.
author: Brian H.

description:
The Asian lady at the coffee bar is awesome and always makes the best 
bagels!
author: Maurine F.

description:
I love Canyon Market!
The food and produce is wonderful. 
The staff and owners are VERY nice and helpful.
The selection is interesting of high quality.
They're locally owned. 
Of course they're more expensive than Safeway - they're also not a huge corporation selling mediocore products.
WORTH EVERY PENNY! Thanks Canyon Market!!!
author: M.E. T.

description: Best gourmet food market ....can't get enough of the nopalitos salad & the fruit & yogurt parfait
author: Alma M.

description: This place is beeeutiful! Everything smells great, looks great & tastes great. It's an independent store, so yes, it will be pricier, but damn - look at the selection!
author: Em L.

description:
While it's incredibly useful to have a supermarket just across from GP BART, I have to say that Canyon Market is damn expensive and products never seem to go on sale.

Most of my purchases have been produce related, bought just before I head home to make dinner.  Most of the fruit and veggies are organic and good quality, but I always try to limit myself to absolute necessities so I don't feel like I'm getting shortchanged. 

I do appreciate their deli counter where you can pick up a wide variety of cooked items as well as made-to-order sandwiches. Their sandwiches range between $7 - $8, which is reasonable. For baked goods and baguettes, I much prefer Destination Bakery. 

Nice to have an independently owned market here, just wish it were a little cheaper.
author: Joanne G.

description:
Canyon Market has grown on me. It's definitely NOT the store you'd depend on for your everyday grocery needs but it serves a useful purpose in Glen Park. The expensive meats? They are great quality and great for a little indulgence. Seafood is fresh too. I get if you need to get out at Glen Park this place is good for that. Charcuterie and cheese selection is great too. Here's what I find lacking still:

- Beer is still way overpriced
- The bread they bake in house is good but it's inadequate. They need to start selling some other bread (Acme, please!?) and they sell no buns other than prepackaged burger buns
- Their heirloom tomatoes are always expensive, even in season but they're always awful and cardboard flavored. You need to change your heirloom supplier. Otherwise, other produce is quite good. 

Otherwise, good neighborhood market.
author: Steven H.

description:
I recommend this great shop for key essentials:

Salad Bar (rocks!  Try the Shallot dressing.)
Meats  (Have them slice you some fantastic salami for your next party.)
Catering Foods behind the deli counter (Try the green bean salad, etc.)
Breakfast bagel  (with Gruyere, egg & bacon, double yum!)
Baked goods (cupcakes, cakes, pies, crumbles, oh my!)

I would avoid some of the produce, which is not cost effective and seems to go limp/stale earlier than it should.

Other than not being particularly cost effective (2 bags of groceries here seem to routinely cost $100) this place is wonderful.  Of coarse, this cost may be due my succumbing to their extremely tempting deli/catering section.
author: Rachel H.

description: Very Very Expensive. But it's good in that it's convenient to pop into, has some interesting groceries including a huge cheese selection and also sells some decent sandwiches at the sandwich bar.
author: amber h.

description: Yes, it's more pricey than Safeway, but the qualities ten times better.    Staff is friendly, large selection of produce, nice deli,  home made bread,  they make rye a few days a week (the bread, not the whiskey) .    Flowers, great coffee.    I'm glad it's in GP and it adds a lot to the neighborhood.
author: Dennis N.

description: Love a good local market with a great meat department and fresh produce. Why have I never stopped in here before? Next time, I'll have to try some of their twice daily freshly baked bread.
author: Tina Z.

description:
What impresses me about Canyon Market is the size of their open kitchen.  It takes up 1/3 of the store.  Even better, they have a great baker on staff.  I rushed over when Jonas T. recommended their cupcakes.  When you first walk in, you'll see their coffee kiosk to the left.  This isn't where the cupcakes are. The cupcakes are on the left side of the kitchen area near the house baked breads.  They're sold individually and also in 4 packs.  Flavors rotate.  On the day I visited, I saw three flavors (chocolate, vanilla, red velvet).  The cupcakes are a little smaller than usual as they don't have the height of most other bakeries.

* Vanilla cupcake with lemon buttercream and a fresh blueberry: Excellent cake: moist with visible vanilla bean specks.  The frosting was creamy, lemony, bright, and not too sweet.  It was colder and a little harder than I prefer but still very good.  

* Chocolate cupcake with chocolate ganache: Dense, high quality chocolate flavor.  The cake was a little too dense in my opinion, making it more like a brownie.  The frosting was rich, creamy, and not too sweet.

The salad bar is $6.99/lb, cheaper than Whole Foods and Harvest.  I tried a couple of salads and thought they were good but not as good as the aforementioned places. The polenta triangles were slightly sour.  I did like how they make their own croutons.  Nice touch.  

It's a medium sized "health food" market with a meat/seafood section, bakery with their own breads, deli, wine section, produce department, frozen foods, interesting drinks, gourmet cheese, and a good supply of tofu, seitan and made to order sandwiches.  They don't have their own parking which always makes me buy fewer groceries.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Totally worth the (only slightly) inflated prices, when what you're paying extra for here is pure quality.

I could pay less for produce at Safeway and other markets, but that stuff is easily a heck of a lot less fresh and inevitably always spoils several days before anything I get from Canyon Market.

My only gripe is their lack of variety of sustainable (not farmed) seafood.  I still get my processed/non-perishable stuff elsewhere because it's the exact same products at a lower price.  But otherwise, this is the place for fruits, vegetables, cheeses, bulk foods, phenomenal locally roasted (fair-trade and organic) coffee and most especially: amazing bread!
author: Alyssa H.

description:
Last Tuesday I came in and bought a half pound of roast turkey and a half pound of prosciutto for sandwiches.  I then asked for a handful of sliced red onion and a few pieces of lettuce to make sandwiches at home.  Rather than simply saying "I have to charge you for that", which would only have been mildly offensive, they undertook an elaborate explanation about being "short" of onions and lettuce at the sandwich station, but they were available at the salad bar, and they proceeded to put sliced onions in a container that could be weighed and priced.  The extra charge was $1.57.  I'm sure the cost was about 25 cents.

As a regular customer I spend about $50-$75 a week at the store buying prepared foods.  They are expensive, even over-priced, but I always figured that was a trade I was willing to make for convenience.  Also, on one occasion I bought 4 sandwiches that made all of us sick within 3 hours, but not for a minute did I think of asking for my money back.  On another, I bought $57 worth of filet mignon that, when I got it home, was clearly on its last leg.  Again, I didn't think of returning it.  It's all part of the give and take of the neighborhood retail experience.

The charade of being "short" on onions and lettuce at the sandwich station, but having more than enough 20 feet away, tore it for me.  Thinking like any small business owner, they were consumed with anything going out the door for free, and instead needed to squeeze the last nickel out of me (or any other patron).  It was offensive, especially given that I am a frequent customer.

So I hope they enjoyed that $1.57.  They could have bought enormous good will by just giving me a few onion slices.  Instead, I will no longer shop at the store on a regular basis.  More than likely I will buy the few things that I really want on occasion, but the regular sales won't recur.  I figure that to be about $3,000 a year.  Multiply that by the number of other patrons who have no doubt been similarly offended and they are talking real lost business.  They already have a reputation for being over-priced.  Why compound it with being downright cheap?

And for the record, both Tower and Rick's shop (around the corner from you) routinely hand out a few onion slices upon request.
author: Hal M.

description:
This is a great market and all, but it's bakery is totally underrated. They have some of the best cupcakes in the city at only $1.75 a pop - Heavey on the frosting but the cake keeps its moisture. Cheesecake (~$4 each) is not bad, but not great. Their deli/meat section is good too.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
Wine Tasting Review:

I know it may sound weird, but they do have wine tasting in Canyon Market.  I didn't believe it myself until some guy, aka Roberto, asked us if we wanted to taste a couple of wines.  Wait.  I take it back.  The Trader Joe's in Las Vegas also had wining tasting once (please refer to future review for details).  Anyways, I was surprised.

Roberto, a self proclaimed wine geek, was very knowledgeable and pleasant.  He pointed out the characteristics to notice of each wine we tasted and then gave us possible pairings.  He did a good job of making two wine novices feel very comfortable.

While we finished tasting the last wine, he mentioned he taught wine tasting somewhere but the classes got a little too crowded and impersonal.  He went on to say that he still likes sharing his appreciation for wine and now does tastings in the more cozier setting of his home.  I'm assuming that it'd be a very pleasant and enlightening experience based on our encounter.  I'll make sure to review it if we go.
author: Dan B.

description:
My friend suggested this place to me and I tried their sandwiches twice, both times were disappointing.

First time, I ordered their crab cake sandwich and I thought they were going to be good, especially for $10, unfortunately, there was way too much filler used in their crab cake and not enough crab therefore making it a fried breading sandwich. It was very disappointing. I cannot say I recommend it.

The second time I came here, I decided to go with something safe: turkey bacon sandwich. Somehow, I don't know how, but they managed to screw it up too. I think it may be because they were trying to be too 'gourmet' about it and screwed up something so simple. The tomato-base sauce they used was far too overpowering so all I really got from the sandwich was tomato sauce and some turkey and not much of anything else. If I didn't know any better, there wasn't even bacon in it.

I did hear good things about their soups though but the one time I did check, there wasn't any soups that sounded interesting to me so I ended up not getting any. The staff was very friendly though, so that's a plus. Definitely 2 stars for their sandwiches (at least the two I tried) and a star for their service.
author: Richard C.

description:
I've been coming here for the past year for the occasional trip to their salad bar during lunch. Decent salad bar but nothing to write about.

But today, I discovered they make an amazing sandwich!!

I got the #1 (salami and coppa with peperoncini and balsamic vinegerrete on ciabatta). They give a pretty basic amount of meat, but the reason I'm writing this review is their bread-it is beyond fresh!! I should have realized this because they do bake their own breads, but it didn't hit me until I took my first bite into this sandwich. The ciabatta was so light and airy, not densed like most ciabatta breads. I couldn't believe how amazing the bread was! The combination of salami, coppa, peperoncini with the balsamic dressing was good, but the fresh-ness of the ciabatta bread definitely made the sandwich!

I'm definitely returning to try their other sandwiches!
author: Liz C.

description: Canyon Market is a GEM.  I love their sandwiches, deli items, and well-stocked-for--such-a-small-space sundries, but lately it's the bakery that has been blowing me away! The yellow cake with chocolate frosting is moist and beautiful, the fruit tarts are cooked perfectly, the chocolate pudding is like comfort food from your childhood with a modern twist . . . the list goes on and on.  Someone in my family literally shops here every day - Canyon Market, I don't know what I would do without you!
author: lighter g.

description:
I get sandwiches and groceries here 4 days a week for my company and also do most of my personal grocery shopping here too.  
First off, the employees are really great!  I don't know all of them, but the guys behind the deli counter and the women at the registers are always a pleasure to talk to.

They don't have too wide a wide selection, but I prefer the quaint/cozy to a mind numbingly huge selection.
author: Paige P.

description: Sarah is the best, coolest sandwich maker around! She should actually be called a sandwich artist and a customer connoisseur.  I saw her interact with other customers and she was equally awesome to them. Thank you Sarah for being the best canyon employee ever!!
author: Amy B.

description:
One of my favorite lunch spots. I LOVE their salad bar especially their poppy seed pasta salad. I've ordered from the deli many times and I've never been disappointed-everything has been delish. 

I've never had trouble finding parking and you could choose to enjoy your lunch in their covered outdoor seating area if you have enough time on the meter. 

Nice staff, especially at checkout.  Overall, a great pit stop in glen park/ off of 280.
author: Valerie A.

description:
Canyon Market is a Rainbow Market mini-me without the monthly coupons (that have gone au revoir) and which has meat . 

If you are as passionate about cooking as I am, then get thee to this market! OMFG-I mean, I have to freaking make a list:
1. The Baked goods-made in house such as whole wheat batard, a HUGE crumb-topped marionberry pie for $14.95 and the best part-a pound cake that you'd swear was really shortbread with a dusting of lovely sugar crystals.-$5.95! 
(This being the age of $27.00 cakes in markets, these prices were refreshing).
2. QUALITY meats-I found Spanish chorizo here! For those of you who make European recipes as I do, this was a godsend. Check out "Olive" magazine from the UK-you'll thank me later.
Niman Ranch pork chops that were
a. Thick, bone-in, juicy cuts.
b. affordable.

Yes, some of their meat is $$$$-but, I guess I know where to go when I must have freshly cut buffalo skirt steak. This is NOT Safeway-but quality costs moulah, not to mention avoidance of those pesky factory farms.

BTW-We were so psyched to find the aforementioned buffalo being cut by the super-sweet Tuffy-famous for her Liver pate and supreme reign as a chef at Delassio's in Falleti's Market in the Haight.  
3. A selection of organic veggies that matches Rainbow's quality (while not as big as theirs).
4. Incense, candles, and a whole bunch of homeopathic medicine and natural skincare products.
5.Gialina's is across the street-'nuff said.
author: Antoinette S.

description: We used to love the sandwiches till they got so skimpy on the meat and cheese. Too bad :(
author: mary k.

description: Love this place so much!  This is a wonderful neighborhood market with friendly and helpful owners and staff, beautiful selection of fresh, high quality organic produce, meats, wine, and prepared foods.
author: Louise V.

description:
Glen Park:  Neighborhood...on the GROW!

At least that's what Eye on the Bay would probably say if they did a feature on this place.  It certainly does stand out in formerly sleepy Glen Park.  In fact the modern exterior and the whole mixed-use thing make it look like a piece of Seattle was somehow warped in here.  Also, is it just me or does this place need a real sign out front?  I must've walked down the other side of the street 3 times before I realized there was a grocery store here.

Those who compare it to Bi-Rite are right on.  It's far too small to be a real competitor to Tower Market or Andronico's.  Which means, if you live around here and can afford it, this place is a godsend.  For me it will certainly warrant an occasional stop when I'm feeling rich and sybaritic.  Just don't forget to keep patronizing Cheese Boutique as well.
author: Wes M.

description:
I really want to give this market a good review...It could be a great neighborhood store.
It's in a convenient location. I have always been treated well by the staff. They have even walked out heavy loads like firewood to the car.  They have a great presentation and organic healthy produce.  

Unfortunately, I have found their food safety practices questionable. 
For the last 18 months I have complained to the staff about the lack of the sneeze guard at the pastry counter.    The pastries are sitting out on a counter right at the nose level of a child.   (I know because I have kids).   Well they finally got a sneeze guard, but the pastries are sticking out 6 inches past the sneeze guard.  Not effective at all.   The thing that actually prompted me to write this review is the fruit bread pudding I brought home yesterday.  I cut it up to feed my kids and it was fuzzy with mold.   I had picked this up at the pastry counter.  It didn't have a made on date so who knows how long this had been sitting out unrefrigerated.  On another recent visit, I saw a bottle of 409 cleaner sitting in the middle of a cheese display, assumable forgotten by a staff member. 

I am sure there is no problem with the groceries and the produce.  But it's best to be cautious when purchasing the in-house prepared food.   Definitely look for a made on date before buying.
author: Dana P.

description:
This has become my favorite market since I moved into the area 2 years ago, but an experience I had with how they addressed a problem sealed the deal for me. Last spring, I bought a couple bags of groceries, including some soft fruit (early-season plums, I think), and when I got home I discovered that they were crushed because the checker put them near the bottom of the bag. I just chalked it up to occasional human error and didn't say anything.

But when the same thing happened -- with the same checker -- 2 months later, I called and spoke to the manager. I didn't want anything except for them to train the checker in question that peaches, plums, etc. shouldn't go into the bottom of the bag. She apologized profusely and promised to talk to the checker, and -- without any prompting -- offered to bring some replacement fruit to my home. She offered to do this before even asking if I lived close by. She came by and delivered the fruit that afternoon, and threw in a few heirloom tomatoes as a way of making up for the inconvenience. 

This is not an isolated experience. These folks treat customers wonderfully, and it's a glorious change of pace from what happens at chain grocers.
author: Bruce M.

description: Great location for folks living in Glen Park area. Good selections for such a small market. Most fresh vegetables are organic. Decent wine selections ... wish they carried more organic wines.
author: Rex W.

description: Wow, they sell my fav, Cowgirl Creamery Mt Tam cheese!  Fresh baked bread, grass fed beef, wish I lived closer this place is so great, their salad/take out bar is a gourmet feast.  Great choice for vegan also.  A little pricey, but for a local store is great, workers are friendly, place is very clean produce is better quality vs Safeways.
author: David K.

description:
Too hipster of Whole Foods?  Want to feel like you are not selling out the man, but are still spending enough $$ buying trendy artisan, organic, local food?  If so, Canyon is the place for you.  

On the other hand if you are looking for Ding Dongs, refined sugar or Pabst Blue Ribbon, better not walk through these doors lest you be tarred and feathered for the SF hipster poser you really are ;-)

Another review called it "Whole Foods Lite" and that is pretty accurate.   for being small, the layout is well done and while the variety is slim, the selection is pretty good.

And as much as i tease and mock, I will be back.  Damn.
author: Bruce R.

description: Love this place & it's super convenient location to me!  Their salad bar and hot food bar are quite tasty and their selection of spreads, hummus, and salsa have me coming back for more!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
The only negative about this market, is that it is so darn hard to find parking if you don't live close enough to walk.  I would go here more if I couldn't only get a spot.

Otherwise, sometimes I'm lucky and I get a treat of a really good sandwich from the deli, and a delicous salad.  Everything here looks fresh, and delicous - a bit more pricey but worth a treat.
author: Gina C.

description: I love this neighborhood, non big-box grocery store (I don't go there regularly because it's simply too expensive). When I am able to shop there, the last thing I want is to feel like I'm being duped - specifically when buying meats. I like the idea  of a "butcher" but I don't believe that it's actually a group of trained butchers - at the counter or in the back trimming the meats. While they usually can't answer questions about the cuts, what's really frustrating is that for the third time (yes, I know, shame on me), I've bought a cut of meat and didn't remember to say to the butcher "turn it over" - which I really don't think you should have to ask. I don't know how they are trained on trimming cuts of meat, but a 4 year old could do a better job. It's presented as a beautiful cut, and then you turn it over to find an awful cut that is virtually all fat and nasty - something you would never consider buying. Take heed and be sure to inspect your purchase - because it certainly isn't bargain priced and you certainly don't get what you paid for.
author: LC C.

description:
Although this place can get a bit pricey, its one of my favorite go to markets! 

I'm not the biggest fan of salad bars and soup bars at grocery stores because you always see people picking at stuff with their fingers and thats so unsanitary! Who wants to eat something that people have put their fingers in right?! Manners people! Anyways, the salad bar here is usually very clean and they provide lots of different pasta salads and gourmet olives along with your regular salad toppings such as corn, pickles, croutons, fruit, etc. 

Their soup bar always has three different types varying everyday. Sometimes I see chili, homemade clam chowder (yum!), chicken noodle, split pea, etc and etc. The list goes on and on! 

Their already made products are also amaze balls! They have at least 20 different options from veggies to seafood to roast chicken to pasta and etc. I always get their calamari salad which is mixed with red bell peppers, capers, olives, red onions and parsley at about $13 a pound. Sounds expensive but if you ask for a scoop full it comes out to be less than $3! :) They also have a long list of sandwiches they can make for you which i haven't had yet, but my mom says they're pretty amazing! 

This market also has its own little coffee shop to the side once you walk in the doors! I haven't had their coffee or tea yet, but I do like their pastries especially the coffee cake with walnuts (yum!). The only thing I don't like is that their pastries are all put out in the open where flies can fly around and bugs and what not. 

The only downside to this market is that parking sucks! But other than that, give it a try, you will not be disappointed!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I'm a neighbor and almost daily visitor of Canyon Market and I love shopping there.  

And because Canyon provides a wide variety of convenient, high quality products in a compact space, their prices are higher than larger stores.  The prices also reflect the fact that Canyon has a tiny, cramped loading dock on a residential street and very limited space to store merchandise.  

Each weekday morning, I walk past pallets of food on the curb waiting to be unloaded.  Rather than pallets of single items, like cereal or milk, each pallet is loaded with small quantities of dozens of different foods, obviously packed by a distributor.  The fact that they can maintain a supermarket selection of food in a neighborhood market space is a miracle.  

And in this small space is a full-service deli, a salad bar, a flower shop, a wine bar, a bulk food section, a coffee shop and a bakery.  I'm amazed that this business model is sustainable, but I hope that it is.  Canyon Market is the largest of the Glen Park businesses that bring residents together and contribute to a sense of community.  I value its presence and hope that it thrives for many years.
author: Charlie P.

description: I love this market! They have a great selection on beverages and beer, snacks and prepared foods. They even have a small seafood section with sushi grade tuna and salmon which is nice. The sandwiches you can order from the deli-ish area are really yummy.
author: Kajal G.

description:
Um, yeah hi.  So these tomatoes?  I can appreciate that they're organic and local, and contain no heebie jeebies and have MBA's from Stamford and all, but $8 a pound?  ....Really?

Okthxbi.
author: Laura F.

description:
I always thought Canyon Market is to Glen Park as The Good Life is to Bernal Heights, so naturally I've never been in because I can just go to The Good Life...but while strolling by during The Glen Park Festival, the waft of fresh bread lingering outside lured me in.

So, I tried to nonchalantly browse through the groceries but the aroma beckoned me to the deli counter.  I ordered a #2 Ham and Havarti sandwich and a small container of their beet salad.  As I await for my sandwich to be freshly made I walk over to contemplate which drink to purchase.  They didn't have what I was wanting but the employee stocking somewhere in the vicinity saw my distress and helpfully started suggesting everything similar.

We were interrupted by the employee making my sandwich to inform me that they didn't have the bread nor the brussel sprouts that I wanted.  Needless to say, I was a bit bummed.  However, his simper and swift eagerness to make it up to me rapidly turned that around.

Sat at one of their tables outside to soak up some UV rays.  My sandwich and salad was great (shouldn't have told him to surprise me on the mustard...pheww, it was HOT!).  Always love fabulous service though!
author: Ninja H.

description: Canyon Market has a fantastic all organic salad bar and excellent prepared items.  It also makes for a reasonable general grocery store, but you would probably still have to hit Safeway occasionally for certain items.  Prices are a bit high, but probably less than Whole Paycheck for equivalent or better products.  The bread is also excellent.  Also conveniently located less than a block from Glen Park Bart.
author: William N.

description:
Reading recent reviews
I'm low income only shop there for meat and some other goodies- luv canyon!  They are NOT a chain- they buy locally when possible-etc- yes they are pricey because they are not a chain and can't buy in bulk like whole foods safeway- and their food is a trillion times better- support local small businesses folks!!!  do I need to post a vid of how you get your eggs/chicken/meat buying them at safeway/wholefoods- pay a couple bucks extra to support local economy and humane treatment the animals we eat- come on - they even post stories about the farms above the meat you are about to buy- 

canyon rocks-
author: Karen H.

description: 5-stars for the salad bar and the delish,organic, refreshing dishes that keeps you energized for the rest of the day.
author: Beril Y.

description: I dig Canyon Market. They have a good selection of organic food and a small coffee bar. The prices are about what you'd expect from a neighborhood organic store -- pricey, but I think not unacceptable. I also find the staff to be particularly helpful and friendly. There are few stores in Glen Park that I can say I stop is frequently or even often when I'm in the neighborhood, but Canyon is one.
author: David H.

description: Obsessed with the kale salad here. Salad bar in general is super fresh. A little pricey but I don't even really care. Come here all the time and the service is really nice.
author: V L.

description: Unfortunately this place has gone from ok to bad in a very short period of time.  The food is really over priced and flavorless.  The owners and employees can't be bothered to not take up the entire sidewalk in front and to the side of the store, so people can walk by and they must think customer service and politeness is a four letter word.  I go to Mollie Stones in the Castro now, the food is tons better, they are locally owned, out of Sausalito and the staff is so wonderful.  Not to mention real sushi, not pre packaged dried out rolls made miles away from the store.   BIG PASS on this place.
author: Stephanie N.

description: Please stop being RUUUDDE check out lady with dark hair..older.  Nice manager yet again corrected your mistake.  Again you were rude and talked down to me.  Why do i keep going in here?????
author: Diane K.

description:
cute local grocery store within walking distance! definitely a bit too pricey to shop here all the time, but there are definitely some standouts that make it far superior to whole foods:
the bread is amazing in all forms. i just can't get enough of it's light, crispy flaky goodness. rumor has it they supply gialina's across the street with their scrumptious pizza dough. i believe it.
obscure cheese aisle. i can guarantee to try something i've never heard of before and consequently fall in love with.
freshly prepared foods are always to die for. whole foods had a great run for a while, but it got old and repetitive quickly. i'm a fan of the small yet well stocked, always incredible cuts of fish too. 
that pesto pasta salad is like crack. same with their guacamole which might just be the best i've ever had that wasn't made to order.

all in all, if whole foods on ocean were to close down, it wouldn't be a huge loss because canyon market supplies nearly the same quality in a cuter, more compact layout. yum.
author: ashley d.

description:
If you want to spend three times the amount of money on the same food you can find anywhere else, this is your place.  

I went here for everyday things, ketchup, bread, a bottle of $10 wine, and how I barely filled my grocery bag, and spent $70.. is beyond me, but my heart jumped through my chest.  

It was my own fault by being intimidated by the rain, and staying local, when i could have walked a few more blocks and saved 40-50 dollars.  My bad!!  

Sorry Canyon Market, but I cannot waste anymore money on you!  Your more expensive than Whole foods!  Yikes!
author: Jeremy G.

description: So fancy, with a price tag to match, but some unique gourmet items worth grabbing for host/hostess gifts.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
I generally stop in every now and then for a salad, and not much else, as the salad bar is fairly decent.   There once was a time when I shopped here, probably shortly after it first opened.  I quickly learned my lesson fast.  The prices here are just as bad as Whole Foods.  Save your money and head on over to Trader Joe's where $100 goes a long way.  

Also, wheat/gluten allergy information isn't posted for their salad bar choices and deli prepared food items.
author: Ally C.

description: I wouldn't make this my go-to grocery destination but that doesn't seem to be their goal; if I need to pop by on the way home for a quick something to complete a recipe, grab a spice I'm missing, etc?  This does the trick.  Expensive?  Yeah, very, and as others have said the Alemany Farmer's Market is a spectacular alternative for keeping your staples stocked.  But when it's 8:45pm and you need something quick, it's nice to have it here.
author: Adam H.

description: Beware, all that glitters is not gold.  Despite high prices, this market is not high end.  They use old meat and fish in their 'homemade' soups (and you can taste it).  They have the unseemly practice of changing the 'prepared on' dates on their homemade, pre-weighed salads and deli items.  In fact, they put expired items back out on the shelf even after they have been made aware of them and removed them.  Even if I did not have to worry about consuming out dated food, I would not recommend Canyon Market.  Their deli counter is sub par with mediocre salads and premade food that pretends to be gourmet, but is certainly not.  Want food poisoning?  Visit Canyon Market!
author: Ana Q.

description:
The only place in the universe thats more expensive than Whole Foods !!!
I only go ther because it is the only good market in the neighborhood. Its clean, but lacks in selection, the staff arent very helpful or friendly, the salad bar looks tired all the time, and the prepared foods doesnt match that of Whole Foods. All in all, disappointing, but all there is in Glen park to buy quality food, vitamins, etc.
author: Dave S.

description:
Obviously if you're going to compare Canyon Market prices to Safeway prices then you shouldn't be shopping here.  Safeway is for bargains...some of the quality of the produce at certain Safeway branches is only a few notches above Foods Co.  
I came to Canyon Market to check out the quality of their meats and produce.  I was happy with the selection and availability of products. 
My baguette that I was purchased was a bit over-baked and I'm not sure if that's common but I wouldn't mind trying more stuff from their bakery and deli at some point.  
The staff here was very nice, love it!  I will definitely return to stock up on a little bit of produce if the vegetables at Safeway are looking droopy and sad again.
author: Amber R.

description:
I specifically come here for Greek Yogurt!!  They always carry the brands that I want!!  

Chobani Greek yogurt (strawberry flavor) is the best!

I also bought the other brand..Greek God (I forget the actual name) to make a comparison.

greek yogurt+ natural granola+raisin= my favorite breakfast!

The selection and prices of greek yogurts at Canyon Market are unbeatable. ($1.75-2.50) which is about the same as Trader Joe's. 
I'd rather frequent to Canyon Market than Trader Joe (even though there are more Trader Joe stores and because TJ doesn't carry Chobani or the other brands that I like.)

Thanks for making me a huge fan of greek yogurts!!  =D
author: Lulu L.

description: There really could not be a better place to shop if you are on the south side of the city.  The option to buy raw milk from claravale and the freshest organic and seasonal items are such a bonus.  The staff behind the counter could not be more helpful if you are looking for a new cheese or interesting product, they go out of their way to be of assistance.  This place is a jem and I love having access to this caliber of market in my hood.
author: Olga E.

description: If you appreciate living a health conscious lifestyle, Canyon Market is the place to shop for organic groceries. Its user-friendly layout is an excellent planogram which makes my shopping very efficient. However, prices are pretty steep if you are expecting to feed a huge family, especially since there is a Safeway less than a mile away up the street. But the deli counter is very good, especially their freshly baked loaves of bread. Great place to buy bread and eggs for breakfast or organic fruits, but to stock up on groceries for the entire month, make sure you save your money if you plan to spend it wisely.
author: Karla M.

description: Beautiful, well-curated grocery with great baked goods and a nice wine selection. Expensive? Yes, but worth it. And I appreciate that they give folks over 65 a 10 percent discount any day of the week.
author: Kate S.

description: A great local market. A little pricey for the most part but makes up for that in service. And the deli is great.
author: Eric S.

description: Honestly, I cannot get behind the prices at this "grocery store". It's not like Glen Park is so far off the beaten path. Am I paying 2 & 3 times what things cost elsewhere for a reason? The annoyingly long line certainly doesn't merit a price-hike, and what are they all waiting for? I'm not impressed with their food either; If I pay 7$ for a ball of fresh mozzarella, it should be pretty descent. They're just not as special as they would have you believe.
author: Maureen M.

description:
Beep beep! Geeze the aisles are small here but look at this high quality grub!

Very expensive
Very convenient [near bart]
Very good food!
author: Bubble B.

description:
When we first moved to the neighborhood, I kept mistakenly calling this store Canyon Ranch, after the uber-fancy spa I've never visited.  I now refer to CM as "the Ranch" when talking to the bf.

I don't do a lot of grocery shopping here, because the selection is pretty tiny.  Yet I'm very thankful to have a place in the neighborhood to buy meat.  I've been gung-ho with clean eating before, & now my approach is more moderate (i.e. I mix in a lil more junk than I ought)... but meat is something I don't like to mess with.  I want it humanely raised, drug-free, etc.  It's not cheap, mind you, but to me it's a priority.

The employees are friendly & helpful, both at the service counters & up front.

I've stumbled on a couple of winners from their prepared-foods counter:  chicken enchilada pie is delicious, as is the chicken tortilla soup (wasn't sure about that, but glad I tried it!).
author: Rebecca M.

description:
This place thinks because they are the only grocery store around, they can just treat you however they want... Seriously if you are going to charge such ridiulous prices you could at least hire staff that is a bit more attentive/ friendly. Specifically I am referring to two times when I was waiting for coffee and the closest checker looked at me and then continued to ignore me! It wasn't until I walked over there, waited for the customer to finish checking out, that I finally said "excuse me, can I get some coffee" that they even acknowledged me and then it was still another few minutes before someone came to help me. 

Oh the plus side, the salad bar and wine selection is actually pretty decent for such a small store... but again service means a lot and this place just doesn't cut it.
author: Rona Y.

description:
Likes:  great fresh baked rye bread, friendly staff, nice layout of foods
Dislikes:  kind of expensive, relatively small selection

Overall, I'm pleased when I shop here but have to be careful not to spend too much.
author: David M.

description:
If you come here for one thing, 

GET A BAGUETTE!

This is by far the best baguette I've ever tasted in the US. (Oh, how you spoiled me, 5+ years in France...) PERFECT glossy interior that I've never seen anywhere else in SF...

I've never been looking for an item for a recipe and not been able to find it. GREAT selection of dairy (hello, Straus milk and yogurt!), De Cecco pasta and amazing prepared foods, so many cooked from scratch in-store.

Really decent cheese selection, great produce, lots of cute local quirks (frequent buyer cards stored at the coffee counter!) super clean, friendly people... 

Bonus points for killer customer service on cold cuts by letting me taste some turkey before buying. I ended up with the house-roasted breast that was less expensive than what I was considering.

I can see how people might think it's expensive, but that seems to be because they carry high-end stuff. I wouldn't necessarily expect them to match Safeway prices on generic stuff, but I would never find Niman hot dogs or sliced-to-order jamon serrano at Safeway, so you decide how much you want to pay for what you put in your body and what kind of community you want to have.

Oh! And I love hitching my mutt out by the chill patio/eating area. Plus, two access doors make it a little less crowded to come in and out. 

BUT DID I MENTION THE BAGUETTE???!!!
author: Alexis W.

description: Convenient. Leaning on the expensive side. Where is the baker that bakes my ham and swiss biscuits and green onions and cheddar biscuits???  It's been two weeks!!  My heart is broken :-/
author: A T.

description: The place is great and food is good. but I it so expensive to shop there. This place is so over priced. I wish there was a Trader Joes  instead.  I under organic healthy food but does it have to hurt my pocket book so much to have this.  I wish they would sell grocery to people who do not make over $100, 000 a year. sorry just my take.
author: Carmen O.

description:
Can you say fresh baked breads twice a day. High quality meat and a very cool staff.
Would get 5 stars but prices are a bit higher than most grocery/market.
Two blocks from the house so I usually find myself there 3-4 times a week.
author: Mike J.

description: I love Canyon Market for their convenience, delicious deli case, wonderful meat and seafood departments and good wine selection. I live in the neighborhood so I might be biased but I'd rather spend a few more dollars on quality food (and save the expense of driving to another grocery store). I find everyone to be exceptionally friendly here, not sure what other people are talking about. I think Canyon Market is a true gem in Glen Park and I will continue to frequent it often.
author: Tom E.

description: Lots of beautiful, sometimes hard to find foodstuffs but I was extremely disappointed to have recently  bought meat there for the second time and found it not fresh enough to consume for the second time.  Two out of two is a bit ridiculous in my book and obvious evidence of a quality problem.  Who cares about it's fancy origins if it smells bad when you open the package (the same day, in case anyone's wondering)?.  Very apologetic does not make up for that.  From now on I will stay away from their meat department.  Other stuff seems great.
author: elizabeth M.

description: Love this market - it actually doesn't seem quite like $$$ to me.  Considering the quality of the food, the flowers, the coffee and the variety, it actually seems pretty reasonable.  The flowers, in fact, are some of the best around and very reasonable.  They make great coffee, tons of quick gourmet offerings and it is a fun place to shop - oh! and BEAUTIFUL cards.
author: Laura M.

description:
Reiterating what I said last time.  In a pinch I picked up some salsa here for a party ($12 for a pint or so.. bastards) and got "Juanita's salsa roja."  More like salsa agua.  This overpriced, watery crap came from someone the owners supposedly know, as they have a little note reminding you how your patronage supports the hardworking local salsa lady *sniff.*

Seriously, screw this place - I've been quite a few times, every time feeling burned after leaving.
author: Scott S.

description:
Just moved to the neighborhood and LOVE this store.  
The selection of food for such a small grocery store is great, and the people who work there are super friendly and helpful.
author: Lisa F.

description: So I really like this store.  It has pretty much everything I need.  I don't do all my shopping here though.  If I would, I'd be broke.  What I love is the quality of their products, especially the soups, salad bar, and items behind the deli counter.  The breads at the front are delicious and fresh baked.  Their guacamole dip is one of the best I've had.  Sesame noodle behind the counter is yummy.   Can't go wrong with the choices in their salad bar.  It's consistently the same albeit a few minor changes every other day (i.e., squid instead of chicken).  It is a bit more expensive than Whole Foods (i.e., Tcho chocolate is $2 more than what's being sold at Wholefoods, Tejava tea (if not on sale) is also higher).  Bottomline, if you're coming in to get a bite to eat and a couple of small items, then this is a great spot.  For all your other kitchen yumminess, probably not.  I'm still a fan of this place and am grateful they exist.  They're close to Glen Park BART which makes it convenient as I park my car in the area and usually grab a salad, soup, or sandwich for the drive home.
author: Nerinna V.

description:
I love Canyon.   Their Butternut Squash lasagna (order ahead through catering) is a great deal if you want to feed a crowd a savory, sweet, and filling main course.   I have also ordered the pinwheel and tea sandwiches and the fried chicken for larger parties.  The potato salad is great in summer.

In my opinion, Canyon can be a great shopping experience if you are focused in your buying.  The selection is selective and therefore might not have the your specific set of basic grocery needs, but you will definitely find items there that you'll come back for again and again.  I love the soup and chili selections at the salad bar and the roasted chickens from the deli case.
author: Mary H.

description: Ive never been unsatisfied when I've shopped here. The workers are very friendly. The Daily Soups are really good from the salad bar, so are the sandwiches. It can get pricey sometimes but its worth it! MMMM Love this place!
author: Isabel L.

description: Located 2 blocks from the Glen Park BART, Canyon Market is conveniently located local market offering a relatively large selection of organic produce, cheese, deli sandwiches, prepared salad/food options, and specialty items.  They also offer an excellent wine selection.   Although prices lean towards the expensive side, staff is friendly and selection and convenience are much appreciated
author: Kim R.

description:
These guys still can't get it right.  Surly, full-of-themselves service, and nearly singlehandedely stopped Glen Park Village from getting our Farmers Market.  Not a real neighborhood player.
Belongs in Noe Valley, as do most of the patrons.
I prefer the real Mom and Pop businesses in the village and always will.
author: Vernon H.

description:
parking is difficult in this neighborhood sometimes.

the original market that used to be here burned down.  the space was empty for a LONG TIME.  Now canyon is here and they are filled with lots and lots of goodies.  Want me to name them?  I can't too many to choose from.

the only reason its 3 stars is because the prices are inflated and they are like that because of the convenience to the people in the neighborhood.  the bigger supermarkets are too far away to walk.  BUT this place has all of the things you need, plus things you might buy at special bakeries or cheese or whatever.

it gives a vibe of being more health conscious but its just another market.  well, not JUST but its a market and they do what they do fairly well.
author: Bing D.

description:
I huge leap forward in the ongoing gentrification of my once-scruffy, working-class hood. Pluses:

* Great deli section (Egg salad and prosciuto sandwich rocks).
*  Small but high-quality fish and meat counters.
*  Great bakery. Their semolina cake is fantastic. And the coffee counter sells yummies from Destination Baking. Include the new choc.-raspberry moon pie!
*  Really convenient for the people for whom it's convenient.
* House-made rice pudding!

Minuses:
*  Pricey.
*  Limited selection if your looking for "normal" grocery store stuff. (As opposed to the biodynamic version that costs three times as much.)
*  Can never quite decide if the staff is laid-back, rude or spoiled. Or I have an intermittent invisibility problem.
author: David B.

description:
Why is Canyon Market in Glen Park?  It would be better suited in Laurel Heights with the prices they charge...I mean ridiculous.  Granted they have some nice sandwiches from the deli counter but if you live in Glen Park and need anything you are wasting your time.  Climb in your car and drive to either Safeway in Diamond Heights (if they have what you need) or better yet drive to the closest Trader Joe's

This place seriously needs better pricing and management.  I mean this is GLEN PARK!

I can't see myself shopping there again anytime soon!
author: Dave S.

description: Canyon Market is the best. It's smaller and more expensive than Whole Foods, but their organic food selection is top-notch, their produce is fresh and local, the people are friendly neighborhood folks, they bake their own bread and it's just generally a warm, pleasant place to be. The owners live in the neighborhood and are in the store more often than not. Highly recommended.
author: Julio A.

description:
Great pre-made foods, awesome cheese selection that they will cut to order, decent  bulk section and great customer service. Only thing stopping this from being a 5 star place is that some of the prices are kinda high. 

All in all, I like Canyon Market and always come back.
author: Laura P.

description:
What a neighborhood market should be! Has everything you need for your daily life, great prepared foods for those nights you don't want to cook, a good cheese selection, and even fresh baked bread!

Canyon Market specializes in natural and organic food. For those of us who regularly shop at natural foods stores, the prices are very competitive - especially for produce. If you only shop at Food for Less or Safeway, yes you may have a little sticker shock, but your belly will thank you.
author: Jammy M.

description:
I'm giving this place one star because I can't give zero stars.  Everything is way too expensive and the workers are rude.  Basically this place just sucks, it is way too over priced, and everything here could be found at Trader Joe's. Nothing special at Canyon Market.
You could probably find better customer service at a local Safeway.
author: Joyce C.

description: I go out of my way to shop here for 2 reasons 1) top quality goods with excellent customer service 2) family owned and operated! Richard and Janet are amazing people and they built this thriving store from the ground up with lots of love and hard work...I always feel good about spending my hard earned cash here!
author: Zen D.

description:
Got their smoked salmon spread (must try!), freshly-baked bread, and some smoked gouda cheese and I was in heaven.

Not the cheapest place but they have a good selection of spreads, appetizer foods, and cheese.
author: Tina T.

description:
I love this little market.  Like others have said, my first time in I thought it was way too small, not much in there and WAY expensive.  A few weeks later I realized they were not fully stocked or set up yet and that I should have given them a chance.

So glad the hub and I went back.  I LOVE the homemade soups!  My faves are the Chicken Tortilla and Chicken Veggie with different pastas.  Sometimes rizzoto, sometimes elbow, etc. My dad LOVED the 7 Seas Fish soup.  I mentioned to him that it sounded gross to me and he said his grandma used to make fish soup and asked me to get him some next time they had a pot.  Again, he LOVED it.  I did taste it, and it was good.  BIG chunks of salmon!   And their fresh baked rolls to got with it?  Yummy.

The hub and I are now regulars Saturday and Sunday morning at their little coffee corner.  Having been a fan of Martha's for years on Cortland, we still are but the LINE was becoming such a pain and pretty much a bad way to start a day.  (can we say GROUCH inducing?)  So we decided to try Canyon one morning months ago, and still are never in line behind more than two people...if any.  And their pastry?  Omg!  Most is made there, a few things I saw a little sign of what bakery it's from.  I have had to stay away from that little glass case.  Too many of their chocolate croissants have ended up on my ass.

Yes, it's a little expensive, but I like the things I like so I pay.  I agree I wouldn't do my shopping there.  It's kind of like a "gourmet" or "need a couple things and don't want to go to Safeway" store.

As far as the meat/butcher?  Never bought anything because to be honest?  Some of the meat?  Looks like it's been there way too long.  I am really picky about my meat, poultry and fish, and so far have seen nothing appetizing in their cases.  I admit, I don't look at it often when in there due to not being interested...so I have no idea if it's improved...or just had a bad day or two.
author: Yvonne M.

description:
Man...come on.  I keep trying to give this market the benefit of the doubt because it is, after all, in my neighborhood.  But now, I've decided once and for all to walk my happy ass to Mission for veggies instead.  

Customer service is crap.  I'm a pleasant gal--be nice!!!  Is it so hard to say "hello" or "thanks"?  I don't think so.  It's possible, nay, probable that the only criteria for being a checker here is that you hate people.

The food's pricey as well which is somehow (and sadly) not surprising.  And actually I do like some of the products they sell so...I'm kind of screwed and may have to just deal with all their unpleasantness.
author: Katherine P.

description:
Canyon Market, a few reasons I'm a fan:

- friendly, helpful staff
- good selection of local, organic produce, free range/organic meats
- great cheese selection, good deli
- fresh, local artisanal breads
- even homemade pizza dough (fresh or frozen)

sad when they ran out of pizza dough the one night I was going to buy some fresh to use that night, but it inspired me to make my own

also love that you can order in advance and just pick up your whole grocery order with your car

long story short if you like food you will like Canyon Market
author: Abby W.

description:
My go to local healthy food store. When I can't get to Rainbow (which is 3 out of 4 weeks of the month) I go to Canyon.

I love the olives in the salad bar and the nice variety of breads. 

The chai at the coffee bar is the best!
author: Shannon B.

description:
Good point: nice natural market in the home towny feelin' Glen Park
Bad point: pricey. like. wow. 

They mark their wines up almost as much as restaurants (250%). So if you like a wine at Trader Joe's for $8.99, then expect it to be around $21.99 at the Canyon Market.  

Everything else is fresh and nice. Just not recommended for staples (like wine ;)
author: Leslie F.

description: Has everything you need to pull together a party, but lacks one very important quality: appreciation for your customers who are reaching deeply into their pockets, believe me...bottom line....I was treated very rudely by one of the cashiers (dared to return an item....noticed when I was leaving that I had purchased the wrong thing and turned right around and went to the open counter...different lady than had checked me out and, boy, was she sour....would not give me back my receipt, no way, and I didn't haggle about it)  I won't be shopping there again.
author: Susan V.

description: I want to like this place- it's pretty, but I always leave annoyed and thinking "why did I pay that much for this?" I can appreciate the local stuff they get, but I think they are really over-priced here. I also hate how its nearly impossible to manuver the store.
author: Ashly M.

description:
I love this little store. It is very expensive BUT the produce is very good, the butcher section is awesome and very accommodating.
The staff is friendly, courteous, knowledgeable and environmentally aware.
If they could be a little cheaper, it would be amazing, but even so, I give it 5 stars.
author: dorit g.

description:
I have a feeling I'm gonna be shopping here a lot.

I just moved to Diamond Heights and this place is a block from the Glen Park BART Station so its easy to stop in here between getting off BART and hopping on the 52 to schlep me up the hill.  

Prepared foods are so helpful when you work a lot and don't have the time or energy to cook.  The yummy salad bar is chock full of great options.  They have a nice, small fairly reasonably priced wine selection.  And they carry Stubbs marinades and sauces which I love.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Being a life-long GP resident, I had high hopes for this new market.  When they first opened, I gave them the benefit of the doubt when I encountered overpricing, limited selection and rude customer service.  When the owner asked my opinion about what type of items he should carry, I stayed hopeful and continued to shop.  The only shining light was the butcher case. Seriously, how many types of cheese does one store need to carry? Especially when there's an excellent cheese shop a few feet away (and their hummus and deli items are so much better than canyons).
After nearly 2 years, the owners should have gotten it right but sadly, the selection is minimal, prices outrageous and the clerks remain rude and uninformed.
author: theresa k.

description: Canyon is selling Bourgogne Cote Chalonnaisse 2011 Pinot Nior at $14.99. Don't waste your money.
author: Maisie B.

description: This market really does get what locals want. Fresh, local products...yes with boosted prices of convenience. Now as for "Good Life Grocery" in Bernal Heights... C'mon, most items can be found at Safeway for way cheaper (yes yes, I am aware how evil supermarket behemoths are...) Out of all SF 'hoods, Bernal Hts. deserves a savvy food market with integrity...like Canyon!
author: Jesada P.

description:
This just opened market in the Glen Park neighborhood sports organic and natural foods.  I was passing by and barely noticed that it has opened ... even though I am there almost every day.  It seems they don't have everything in place, but they will soon.

You can get organic fruit and vegetables, as well as snacks and packaged baked goods.  They also have a small meat counter, deli, and a good selection of organic cheese.  I perused the salad bar, and it looks and tastes pretty good at around $6 per pound.  You can even add peanuts, almonds and pine nuts.  

It seems pretty pricey, since the person in front of me had two bags of groceries and the bill was $90.

And I thought this was going to be a library!
author: Michael M.

description: I love this place. The food selection is awesome, killer sandwiches, the staff is always so friendly. Is it cheap? No, but it's got more character than a wholefoods and probably not much more expensive. Great place to have in the neighborhood.
author: A Z.

description:
I really love the fact that Canyon Market is an 8-minute drive from my workplace. Otherwise, I would likely starve to death or be forced to eat crap. Okay not really, but it's a great place to grab a quick healthy bite. I know, I know it's overpriced but really, what isn't in San Francisco? Would I shop there for my groceries on a regular basis? No, but, I can always count on Canyon Market for a healthy made-to-order sandwich, fresh homemade soups and a few yummy snacks for the drive home.

If parking out front, just don't forget to feed the meter (nowadays a ticket will run you $50).
author: Briar F.

description:
I was surprisingly impressed with this cute corner market.  Open layout, seemingly friendly and happy employees who know many of their regular customers (and customers seem to know employee vacation plans!).  Nice, open layout and a pretty decent variety of grocery items.  I agree with Kristine J's succinct statement: "This new market in the Glen Park area is a financially stable hippie's best friend."

I was only in the area for the Glen Park Festival so I can't say I'll go out of my way to come back here.  But... I swear...my butter croissant this a.m., though quite small, was seriously one of the best croissants I've ever had.  I savored every bite.  Not too buttery (no such thing anyway), not too flaky, a little bit o' crunchy.... juuuust riiiight.
