I tend to crave for perfectly delicious things, so who knows - I might up this to a 4-star rating after a few more visits.

Today's festival reminded me of how much I've wanted to explore this SF neighborhood.  Conveniently located just down the way from the Glen Park Bart station.
author: Olma M.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!  

I am the type of person that tends to get overwhelmed with too many choices, but I'll complain when the options are too limiting.  Hello Gemini!  Anyhoo, this market falls squarely between those two states so satisfies me perfectly.  Oddly, I dont find it to be all that pricey considering the options and fare for offer.  The seafood is downright cheap and quite lovely... at least 30% less than the whole foods prices for similar offerings.  They are also one of the few markets that carry my beloved Quorn Tenders!  It's across the street from may FAVE taqueria and you cant help but feel cute strolling around in Glen Park.

Today as I was perusing the deli isle one of the sandwich makers talked me into getting a veggie sammie... He said he'd make it hot for me all toasted with melted cheese and sun-dried tomato.  I asked for a half sandwich and he obliged.  The half sandwich was HUGE and delicious and, at only $3.95, quite a bargain.  

Thanks Canyon Market sandwich man... you made my lunch... literally.
author: shannon m.

description: There are both fans and foes of this cute little market.  I myself could point out a few positives and many negatives.  In the positive column, most of the front line employees seem to be good folks. Helpful, cool, friendly.  (There are too many downsides to this place to list. ) What is most disturbing though is how there are always new faces working there. I stop in for the occasional vegetable or maybe some cheese (yes, everything is quite pricey) and always someone new! It makes me wonder why people keep leaving.  Apparently, management doesn't treat the employees very well.  So I think I am going to start taking my business elsewhere.  I'll save some $$ AND support a business that takes care of it's people. Tired of being gouged? Who's with me?
author: Adam S.

description:
I like shopping here for the following reasons:

It's off the Glen Park Bart, near the 26, 52, and 44 bus lines.
This place is very small...so what you'll find is 
A) pay per pound salad bar consisting of lettuce, olives, candied walnuts, boiled eggs, poached chicken, tomatoes, grilled vegetable 
salad, dried cranberries, grilled onions, etc. They also have hot soups...such as a seafood soup and potato leek. It changes daily.
Their sesame dressing and ranch are definitely tasty and fresh.

Their deli counter always has some good cooked/cold items:
Meatloaf, grilled shrimp, grilled salmon, ducklegs (sometimes), hot wings, broccoli salad, butternut squash or yam salad, sushi, grilled vegetable of the day, cold noodle salad (sesame noodles), and other things that vary.

I usually come here for a 1lb of their fresh baked salmon minus the dill sauce. It's cold, but completely moist and tender when slightly heated up. This goes well with a mixed green salad from their salad bar. The butterscotch pudding is also wonderful, and rivals what they service at Lark Creek Steak.

Be prepared to spend about $35.00-$40.00 just for 1 lb of salmon, 1lb of salad, 1 butterscotch pudding.


There are 2-3 small tables out in front to sit if you want to eat in the fresh air, or as most people do it, share your lunch with your dog. Soooo cute.

Minus one star. The cashier's need to smile more and be alot more friendly.
author: Charlene C.

description: Living in Glen Park, this is where I do all of my shopping.  The cheese section is my favorite - lots of local options!  The sandwiches at the deli are delicious and fresh.  I appreciate the variety of options they have - it's just enough so that I don't have to go anywhere else to do all of my regular weekly shopping.
author: Karen L.

description:
My favorite things about this place is their sandwiches; one of the best you have every had. Have em toasted; yummyy.

Salad bar is awesome; salad dressing quite good.

Meat and fish counter, superb nothing short of whole foods in my book.

Keep up the good work and I will shop there as much as possible. Support local businesses. I think this place deserves 4 stars since I am tough critic but I am giving it a 5 stars cuz i live in the neighborhood and it is the best market around.
author: Lo F.

description: Bought a prepared salad on my way to BART/work yesterday....handy....but the mozzarella was bad....moo...stopped in to buy some other stuff on my way home from work today and mentioned it to the clerk.  He was sorry.  Personally I'd have liked to see a little more response, because really, I imagine they do pretty well with their great location in a great neighborhood and their prices.....  So, no more mozzarella salad.  Just letting you know.
author: stella m.

description:
Fabulous sandwiches that are made to order.

My school had a Teachers Retreat day and we ordered sandwiches from here, and my goodness they were delicious. I ordered a hot roast beef and swiss on a baguette. YUM! I usually am not a fan of mustard but the ones used in the sanwich was spicy and grainy and it complemented the sandwich very well. I was only able to eat half, and save the other half for later ( 'twas large!).

I will be visiting you Canyon Market on my 2 week break, you'd better believe it!
author: LiZANN S.

description:
I'm in there at least a few times a week. Great neighborhood market. Richard (the owner) is very cool, and I've had excellent customer service when I've needed attention/had questions.

My shopping goes something like this:
Staples - Trader Shoes (milk, bread, butter, cereal, cheese, canned goods, etc.)
Produce - Alemany Farmers Market
Meat/Fish - Canyon or similar market

So, I typically am in there to grab the entree to be cooked...the fresh fish. grass fed beef, or other fresh meats. I have no problem paying premium for a higher quality fish/meat product - which is what you get at Canyon. (Specifically, the grass fed steaks and pork chops have been highlights.) I will sometimes pick up the fresh breads and prepared foods which are also nice. 

The fruits/vegetables do tend to be quite pricey but in a pinch, do the trick.

For a neighborhood market, I think we lucked out by getting a place like Canyon!
author: Carmine D.

description:
This place is decent.  It's the best place to buy food in Glen Park, but that's not saying much.  They do have a good selection and lots of unique foods, but the prices are a little high.  Example: you can get a loaf of apple bread there for $6.95.  That exact same loaf of bread is available at the Alemany Farmer's Market (by request only) for $4.50.  It's a little bit of a markup, but then again, that's why I like Farmer's Markets.

I don't recommend doing your full-fledged grocery shopping here, but if you're in the area and need to pick some things up for dinner, it's a pretty good option.
author: Chad H.

description: I second everything Jeff P. (below) said. The prepared foods are fantastic and I can see myself spending a lot of money stopping by that fancy salad bar after getting off BART and walking to my house nearby. I just ate an entire half-tub of the Pumpkin Seed Spread (in the housemade spreads section) with Wasa bread at one sitting.
author: Gaelen X.

description: This place is super expensive, but it's one of my favorite small-scale markets. You can get discounts if you purchase credit through Marqeta card, which helps a bit. They have an awesome cheese section and lots of gluten free items (breads and pizzas).
author: Lia B.

description:
I like the Canyon Market despite the high prices; it's a good place to have in the 'hood. My major problem with it is this: I just came from there, and while shopping  I was amazed to see a woman also shopping with a large poodle on a leash. The dog was pulling away and she was trying to rope the animal  toward her. When I got to the cashier I asked if dogs, other than seeing eye dogs or other special needs trained dogs,  were legal in grocery stores in SF. She told me "yes, all dogs are allowed, unless they piss at your feet." I just called The SF Dept of Health who told me otherwise. It is illegal  for non special needs trained dogs to be inside grocery stores (and restaurants, etc).
When I Googled this further, I read how dog owners just have to say (if questioned at all) that their dog is a service dog. No license or paper work required; it's not like a handicapped person showing a special license to park in a handicapped parking spot. Hello?
I like dogs,  but am beginning to lose it with all the dog fanatics in this city ( it was insane enough when the dog owners tried to take over the baseball field in GG Park where my son's team from Lowell was trying to practice; they thought it more important for their dogs to be off lease on the field).
The long and short of it is that I will think twice before entering Canyon Market again, now that I know they welcome dogs in the aisles. Just doesn't go down too well with all their open salad bars and freshly made meals in low refrigerated sections. I think I'll pass, thank you.
author: Naabi B.

description: Cute supermarket with organic options. Very expensive though and it is more costly than Whole Foods. There salad bar is good. Meat section could be improved upon. Parking can be difficult depending on the time of day.
author: Ana G.

description:
In the last couple of months, Glen Park has changed dramatically. In my point of view, for the good (even if it is an effect of the infamous gentrification). One result of this change, has been Canyon Market.

It is a really cute, organic, corner store and coffee bar. Now, it doesn't have everything (does any corner store?) you need but I like to consider it a little mini Rainbow grocery (with meat). They have amazing sandwiches and other fresh deli stuff. The service is also amazing! You won't stand by the deli for less than a minute without being asked if you have been helped, and they don't glare at you crazy when you ask for a bagillion samples!

The downfall? EXPENSIVE! However, as most corner stores, you pay for the convenience. And it is nice to have a little store so close to your house!

On a more unimportant note, the uniforms are horrible! Everyone working there looks like a meat packer in that nasty burlap sack shirt!! But don't let that discourage you from trying the Turkey, cranberry and brie sandwich!!
author: Molly W.

description:
An excellent neighborhood market.  Very good variety of products - think of it as a mini Whole Foods.  I've never frequented the salad bar, so can't speak to that.  Sure does take up a lot of inventory in the store, though.

Veggies and fruits always have good selection.  The staff that work in this area are helpful.  I always find flowers or a blooming plant that is fresh and reasonably priced.  

I never see anyone at the coffee counter - so I get my java a few doors down.

The prepared foods (go for the Chicken Enchilada Mole!) are quite good.  Good cheese offerings (but lacks smoked mozzarella after asking several times), and some wine specials that are good too.  Small, but excellent selection in the meat department (prices are steep).  Fresh breads and bakery offerings are excellent.  The organic, non-gluten, vegan options are excellent.

I do agree with some of the other comments about staff.  As a rule, they are not service oriented.  It is curious that I come here every week - for over 2 years - yet always treated as a stranger.  I can walk into Tower/Molly Stone and I will be greeted - "Hi, there, neighbor!"  At Canyon, I've never been treated rudely - but far from neighborly.  As such, noone ever makes recommendations.  At Tower, if I pick up a bottle of wine to look - the wine guy will comment on it and recommend other offerings depending on what I'm looking for.  And before I know it ... I've selected 3 bottles!  

At Canyon - if I ask, I get an answer.  It seems they have plenty of staff - but they seem to prefer to speak to each other.  Not help their customers.

I think this is one area that would help build customer loyalty.  And allow customers a method to request special items.  Please ... smoked mozzarella?  More goat cheese offerings?  Maybe have small notepads at the checkout to ask "Is there a product you wish we carried?"

Some customer service training ... practice making eye contact, smiling and greeting might be easy fix for the current aloof atmosphere.  

This aside, I obviously keep coming back.  Its the best grocery option for Glen Park, Sunnyside, Mission Terrace, etc.
author: Patricia W.

description:
As a Glen Park resident, we soooooooo needed this.  It's gotten better since it's opened and I will try to support it so that it stays open.  

I'd compare it to Good Life in Bernal, or Bi-Rite, but without the claustrophobia.  It's very spacious in it's brand new building. Good Life still has the best sushi in a box.  Canyon has their own bakery and the Olive Ciabatta bread is great with enormous whole olives in it.  The produce is in good shape, decent wine/beer for a store it's size, the fish looks ok but I haven't bought any as I usually go to Drewes Bros for meat.

That said, it's too expensive to do ALL your shopping.  But it's delivered every time I've had an "oh crap I need a ___" moment for a few things, or just dinner.

But the weirdest thing - ok, maybe coolest thing - is one of the guys who works there.  A real SF character. He worked, or maybe still works, at the smoke shop on Church near Market.  You've probably walked by and there's been Zeppelin blasting out of there, and he's in there looking kinda tweeky and sometimes singing along.  THAT guy.  I've talked to him a couple times, he's funny, but a little bit of a loose cannon.  Anyway, it was just surprising to see him working here at Canyon Market, I'll try to get to the bottom of it.
author: christoph s.

description:
I'm at Canyon Market probably at least once a day, and sometimes twice.  We live nearby and this is one of the few alternatives that we have to Safeway.  I love the Canyon, not only for their delicious produce, their tempting wines (and wine tastings) but also for their quirkiness.  Where else can you buy a pound of pancetta, a box of egg replacement, a bottle of Campari, biodegradable compost bags and a few yummy coconut macaroons?  That's right, almost nowhere.  While some products tend toward the pricier side, it is nothing like the crazy sticker shock at Whole Foods.  Also, I'm really grateful for the little signs they put up letting you know why the limes are expensive, or why the onions look kind of funky.  

While I've read mixed reviews on Yelp about the Canyon, the best I advice I can offer is that you drop by and see if it fits with you, if it's your type of food and your type of peoples.  Oh, but don't drive.  Please, don't drive.  There is one tiny lot nearby that's supposed to be for BART parking, and other than that there is little to be had street parking.  Since the market went in, traffic congestion has gotten a lot worse on that corner and I've seen a lot of near accidents caused by double parking.  So, instead of driving take BART, because it is literally across the street.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
I love the soups here. They're my go-to for a quick dinner that's healthy and fast. The bread is great too; especially the olive loaf (challah needs a little more love). 

And the flowers are lovely out in front. Sometimes when I'm walking home I pick some up for my wife.
author: Michael K.

description:
My 4 stars are almost completely a result of the salad bar, which actually has chicken that is not slimy and oddly-colored. Since moving to San Francisco 2 years ago, I have been searching far and wide for a decent salad bar.  Is this a little insane?  Quite possibly, but that's just who I am.

As far as being overpriced, well it is an upscale market and you probably shouldn't do your regular shopping there.  So yeah, if you load up your cart, then don't be surprised when the bill is high.  

Finally, as far as the customer service at the counter that everyone keeps complaining about, who cares?  I would never even notice that unless they were overtly insulting.  Just relax people.
author: Erica O.

description: What's not to love about Canyon Market? They have great food, they are close to BART, nice staff, clean environment.  I just can't give them 5 stars because the prices are too high.  I understand a small price hike, because they are a family owned business, but the prices make it impossible for me to do my major shopping there.  That said, I shop at Canyon Market a lot for small things, and they are great.
author: Maggie B.

description: Ah, too bad we moved out of the 'hood. I go back for the mole and the occasional sandwich. Produce is great, too
author: E H.

description: Great neighborhood grocery store.  Can get my "homeopathic remedies" here and fresh baked bread.
author: Kim K.

description:
this place is great!  what a bummer that others haven't reviewed otherwise.  yes, it is expensive, but another reviewer hit it on the nose by saying that if you look at this place a convenience store (well, kinda like the nicest, most gourmet convenience store ever) then you won't be disappointed.  

their deli-made sandwiches are to die for.  their produce selection is limited, but always fresh.  and although i haven't gotten anything from their meat department, they sell neiman ranch meats!  yum!  

prices aside, canyon market is in an ideal location with top-quality offerings and staffed full of friendly folks.
author: Ali L.

description:
Canyon Market is not a place to shop for all of your grocery needs. In that respect, it is very pricey. However, it is a good place to go to pick up basics like produce, cheese, freshly baked bread, milk etc. Far better quality then anything you would pick up at Safeway. 

A big bonus for me is its very convenient location, down the street from Glen Park BART. 

I'm not sure why people have a problem with the staff. EVERY time I go in, the staff is incredibly friendly. I often just look at what is in the cases in the deli while I get in line, just to see what they have. The people behind the counter consistently ask if I need help with anything but every time I just tell that "I'm just looking."  The people at the checkout are fast and always friendly! 

I really enjoy having Canyon Market in the neighborhood. It has saved me many times on the way to a friend's house to pick up a few things to eat/drink at their place.
author: Amanda W.

description: Cute cute cute little market. Being an East Bay girl, I rarely make it past the Mission district when out in the City. But Glen Park is a super cute neighborhood. If I lived in SF, I'd consider moving to Glen Park. This shiny little market full of  little organic gems. It's like a mini-Berkeley Bowl but smaller and shinier. Of course the produce is more expensive but it's SF, that's to be expected. All of their products appear to be handpicked, even if they're not. The deli displayed some creatively delicious looking dishes. They also sell my favorite Burt's Bees coconut foot cream for a $1 less than Wal-Greens! Would love to make another visit soon!
author: Farah S.

description: I didn't want to like this place, but I do.  They have really good prepared food (rice pudding, meatballs, pasta, salad, cobbler) and the staff is truly lovely.  It's overpriced, but I recommend going here for small lunch things, not whole grocery trips.  Sometimes they have sales, but pretty rarely.  It's a very pretty store, but I can't afford it.  One time I asked a woman here if they still had  Hannukah stuff and it was after Hannukah.  She said to me, "It's not on sale, you know," which I thought was a little rude and anti-Semitic, but then it WAS on sale!
author: Julia D.

description:
awesome selection of gourmet food items from Charles Chocolate to cheeses, meats, wine, liquor, vegetables and fruits. With Cheese Boutique and Destination Bakery already in the neighborhood, Canyon Market completes the trifecta. There is a reason Whole Foods is nicknamed Whole Paycheck, the higher quality food will cost more to purchase. The same rule applies here. don't expect Lucky prices for this level of quality.  i had a nice shopping experience here while picking up some NYE celebration items - drinks, snacks, cheese, etc. the courtesy clerk helping bag my items offered help to the car. this happens also at Lucky's and Safeway too. But when was the last time Peter McGowan bagged and carried your groceries. Yes Janet the owner works at the store and we had a nice conversation about the selection of goods and the quality of the products here.
SF supports locally owned and operated businesses and this is one of them that should do very well here.
author: Jeff W.

description: Hi, I wanted to write an update here. Another time I went to this store again... I wanted to get just a bottle of tea. I tried to avoid looking at the cafe. to avoid my own anger.. and was waiting in a long queue. and then out of no where the guy from the cafe came to me and told me that he could ring me at the cafe counter, since I had only one bottle. I think he felt bad from the last time :) he did not apologize or anything, but he helped me pay at his counter and I dint have to wait in the long queue. and he smiled a sorry... I believe in humanity :) I believe that people change and people in the end do care.. so now pushing it to three stars...
author: Ramya V.

description:
Convenient, fresh and friendly. This market is long overdue. It is so wonderful to be able to get off the BART, walk down the street and pick up everything from fresh fruit, yogurt, wine, and pre made dinner(s).
The staff are very helpful and friendly and I feel like a true local when I shop at Canyon.
author: CR S.

description:
I found my holy grail fleur de sel here and only after traipsing throughout the city and not finding it at any of the Whole Foods, William Sonomas and Cost Pluses. I was also delighted to see that they carry a great variety of chocolate bars (Dagoba, Valrhona, and Vosges) and an impressive selection of cocoa powder and hot chocolate (Droste, Scharffen Berger, Dagoba, Green and Black) and probably others that have slipped my mind. And the only reason I even remember these items is because I'm currently on a salt and hot chocolate kick.

Here's a simple and quick way to make your own hot chocolate (because really, don't you get tired of paying $4 for a cup every day? I know I do!) 

- buy a container of good quality, unsweetened cocoa powder. 
- make a paste of a tablespoon of cocoa and a tablespoon of hot water, then whisk in hot milk (or soy milk or cream/half & half) until well blended. 
- whisk in sugar to taste. Add a bit of salt as it brings out the chocolate flavor. If you have bits of chocolate laying around, melt some in with the milk for a richer flavor. 
- if you want to experiment, add a pinch of cayenne, lavender, pepper, sweet paprika, cinnamon, cardamom, or cloves. etc.

OR for a richer drink with actual chocolate, you'll need:

1/2 cup whole milk
1/4 cup heavy cream
5 ounces good-quality dark chocolate, coarsely chopped

- combine milk and cream over medium heat until simmering (about four minutes).
- add chocolate and whisk until smooth. (I like using an immersion blender for a more frothy drink.) Add sugar to taste and serve immediately.
author: Nathalie L.

description: glad they are around because there isn't much else in the immediate area for food shopping. The soups are the best i've tasted. Some things are pricey but not the soup!
author: Eli H.

description:
I'm so psyched that this market finally opened, I could give it five stars just for existing -- but that wouldn't be fair to other businesses. So, four it is.

Yes, the prices can be a bit high, but if you do some comparison-shopping, you may find that they aren't necessarily the worst. (My favorite yogurt cost 25 percent more at both Mollie Stone's/Tower Market and Bi-Rite, for example). And convenience mostly trumps price considerations for me, except for, say, Dungeness crab, which I can get for 40 percent less, and live, at the nearby Manila Oriental Market. Who cares? I can go down the street and get organic vegetables!

I love that the owners have openly solicited and implemented customer feedback. (Be sure to check out the bulletin board on the wall of the store facing Wilder, where the owners have responded to some of said comments and also posted a progress report.) They really seem interested in taking neighborhood residents' wants and needs into account.

The store is sparkling clean and mostly has what I need, although I think they could make better use of their floor space. Maybe they don't have enough stock to fill up, though. And I certainly wouldn't want to store to become as crowded as Bi-Rite. Cashiers are friendly, if a bit green at times -- that's cool.

The gist: Love it. Hope it succeeds. I'm a built-in customer. I have gone and will continue to go there. Hooray!
author: Tara M.

description: It is expensive, yes...mark ups could be a little less.  BUT...I don't care :)  I love Canyon Market.  Close to my house and lots of yummy, specialty food.  Soup and salad bar, deli, and lots of natural and organic options.  It's kind of like a mini Whole Foods.  I always enjoy going in there and the people are always helpful and nice.  There is definitely a good vibe there and happy to have them in my neighborhood!
author: Jennifer R.

description: I am so happy to have Canyon Market in the neighborhood. I try to do all our weekly shopping there with some backup for things they don't carry like sliced Swiss cheese. The best thing about Canyon is being able to get fresh baguettes from the twice a day baking and fresh walnut bread for breakfast. . Also they have good fish and a very decent duck leg to take out. And I almost forgot, a great selection of low cost dry white wines and roses. And the kids at the register are so cute, they always cheer me up.
author: Wendy P.

description:
I was really excited when this place opened, living up the hill from there and having nothing but the crummy Monterey St Safeway on the other side to satisfy grocery needs.  It's a huge plus having a natural/gourmet grocery just a few steps away. 

Pros:
- Nice fresh salad bar
- Tasty deli counter with lots of fresh options including fish, meats, pastas, etc
- Good selection of cheeses and meats, plus breads (though a bit more in that dept would be nice)
- High quality organic (and some non organic) produce
- Good selections of natural pre packaged foods
- Very friendly staff (I don't know what that person above is talking about, I've found all the peeps who work here  really nice)
- Good frozen offerings, including desserts, including vegan (even some Maggie Mudd's!)

Cons:
- Way overpriced. I know the rent is probably expensive for that neighborhood, or whatever, but it feels like literally everything in the store is about 1-2 dollars more than it is at other similar markets. (Granted, you can't get a lot of these things at Safeway, and when you can, like Amy's Frozen Meals, they're usually overpriced too.) But at least Safeway has stuff on sale.  Even small things like sesame noodle salad, which is tasty enough but not that much to it, is really pricey. 
- Fairly small pasta selection (and again, it's overpriced). 
- Would be nice to have a few more pre-made sandwiches
- Less important but it would be nice if they had a few more non-food gift items, like cards, candles, that sort of thing t hat you can find in variety at Rainbow. They have a few and I don't expect a ton in a smallish store, but that could use expanding.
- More cereal, too

Overall, it's a treat to have in the neighborhood, and if you pick and choose what you buy and don't do all your shopping there you won't go broke and will get some healthy, delicious food.  Occasionally I'll go to Rainbow for a bigger natural/gourmet shop, which is a bit less pricey.  But I'm glad Canyon is in my neighborhood.
author: Craigary P.

description: This place is great! I love all the produce its fresh and wonderful. I like that everything is such high quality, I absolutely love the desserts they are fabulous!!! only thing is they area  little bit pricey
author: Veronica V.

description:
Expensive food.  But good food.

If you're into fresh/healthy/organic foods, come on down.  The selection isn't the biggest, but they do have a few somewhat obscure items. I had a lightly sparkling Newman's Own lemonade today from there, I had never seen that before.

When I see the food in the glass display case at the deli, I want to try everything there.  The sandwiches are good.  I like "The Cool Breeze" turkey sandwich and the  ham sandwich.  

I know you're wondering about their cookies at the coffee corner of the shop - wonder no more! They're good.  

This market is on the smaller side, but well stocked, clean, and has a friendly staff.
author: Charles R.

description:
Firstly, the guy who made my veggie sandwich was so nice; he seemed quite genuine, even talking to me about this bad smell and explaining that it was coming from a cheese that had been micorwaved.  He even assured me that my sandwich would be tasty as he handed it to me.  Oh, and the big nice thing was that he let me take a moment to end my cell phone call before he started asking me for my order...tx guy (he was a Black/White mix and I didn't catch his name.)  Unfortunately, the sandwich was good, but not quite right.  Maybe because of the avocado and havarti?  I just know that I was hungry when it was gone, and I like a sandwich to make me feel full.

Okay, for the sucky part.  I asked the lady who rang me up for a separate bag for my dishwashing fluid.  What did she do?  She put the stuff in a really thin brown bag that would NOT safeguard against leaks and then put this in my bag of groceries.  As I was walking home, I also noticed that she put the dishwashing fluid UPSIDE DOWN in the thin little brown bag which was in my main brown bag of groceries...and you know what, found out later that they had plastic bags!!!  ugggh.  When cleaning solutions are not kept separate, they can and have leaked all over the place.

And sucky part 2...So I thought that at least a cupcake or 2 from their bakery would be nice to relax to, at home, and I was soooo wrong.  They were not very flavorful at all; I felt like I was eating just creamy fat as the frosting.  I've  had better cupcakes that weren't marketed all fancy either.  $7.95 for 4 cupcakes for no flavor and plenty of calories!

I go to Canyon because it's a convenient jaunt (that's right, used that word) from the BART station, but perhaps I should have gotten my butt in gear and driven to the Safeway on Mission St. or in Diamond Heights.
author: LoLo A.

description:
Canyon!

I love shopping here. The selection is great and the in-store made food is fantastic. They also bake and make a pretty good mocha. I go there all the time because it's so conveniently close to Glen Park BART.

I removed one star for prices, somethings are way overpriced.
author: Angela K.

description:
This place is convenient if you live in Glen Park and you're into healthy food and you need something really quick. However, ideally I'll make the time to drive to rainbow or somewhere else for my main groceries because this place is really overpriced, like other people have mentioned.  

However, they do have great quality dairy and pasture-fed meats.  Their bulk section is pretty small, their produce is ok.  They don't carry some more specialty things I think they should, but the staff do seem responsive to suggestions.  I wouldn't do my regular everyday shopping here, but I"m glad it's around.
author: Carlin S.

description:
Using a used DIAPER CHANGING TABLE in any way in a grocery store is just GROSS. This was observed Sept. 22, 2009 and again in Dec. 2009.
At the prices this grocer charges they should be able to afford a new shelf.
FEB. 2010 - still using the old diaper changing table. I ran in to buy salad greens and decided I could do without a salad.
author: Dixter D.

description: On my continued mission to try every Red Velvet Cupcake I can find in the city, I saw a box of 4 in the bakery and snatched them to the checkout counter right away. I really enjoyed that they used beet juice to bring out that lovely red blood color to the cake instead of using artifical colorings. Although the cake was a little on the drier side, the frosting was absolutely perfect and delectable! It had a nice balanced cream cheese flavor, not too sugary but sweet enough, and very creamy. It was also topped off with cute little red sprinkles.
author: Geneva X.

description: Cute little market. Very friendly and attentive to your needs. A decent selection of quality foods to choose from if you are ever in Glen Park.
author: Minh V.

description: So I have been GETTING MANY BAGUETTES from Canyon Market since it opened.  They used to be the best.  Recently things have taken a turn south with the texture and they're now as hard as an aluminum baseball bat.  They are either a.  cooking at a higher temp; b. over cooking; or c. they added instant cement mix to the flour.  My wife was worried our kids were going to crack a tooth.  I said maybe they are in cahoots with Calvert Jang & Associates (insert cheesey smile)  I even broke out an old Ginzu knife, you know, the one that can cut through a nail and still slice tomatoes paper thin.  Tore the sucker to shreds.  Okay, okay, I'm over exaggerating, but guys, please go back to the slightly crispy exterior and warm yummy bread.  Please?
author: John C.

description:
I would live here if the rent weren't so high.
No, for real-- it really is great.  Wonderful, fresh and organic produce, and a fantastic meat department.  The prices kill me sometimes, though.  Once I ordered a piece of fresh raw salmon from the meat department to take home to cook for dinner.  When I got to the cash register, the man rang me up and the bill was $32.00!  For one piece of wild salmon.  Wow... I had to take it back to the meat department.
The other thing that they are missing sometimes are their selection of fresh herbs.
Overall, like I said earlier, I would live here if the rent weren't so high.
author: Sarah F.

description: I think this place is racist, and I stopped coming here. When I would come to Canyon Market to order a sandwich, their entire deli staff, which is about 7 people, would just completely ignore me. Even after trying to get their attention, they go to the person next to me, behind me, and people who arrive after me. Also, the staff in general, they have very poor customer service skill. They never smile, never say hello, and the cashiers look like they just want you out of there. Everything is also expensive, and I wish the old Diamond Market was back.
author: Gabriel T.

description:
Canyon Market is a nice neighborhood grocery store, on the high-end, gourmet side of the spectrum.  There's no parking lot, but in Glen Park you can usually find some sort of street parking nearby. 

Here you'll find organic produce, a limited, but respectable wine selection, meat and sea food counter (I noticed they had goat! I need to try that sometime - note to self), salad bar, olive bar, soups, good selection of cheeses, and other gourmet food items.

This isn't a place you'd do all your shopping (at least not the ideal place), nor is it a place to get great bargains, or necessarily a place you'll find obscure things, and there's likely not much point going out of your way to get here.

However, if you are entertaining, or bringing things to a dinner party, and nearby, Canyon Market is a convenient place to pick up quality goods.

I was going to a party, and needing to bring some last minute items (wine, snacks, tea, etc.). It was easy to find the stuff I needed, and checkout was fast and friendly.  And, yeah, it was pricey, but going to Trader Joe's is not always an option. (and to be fair, Trader Joe's may have a larger selection of wines at better prices, but things like produce and meats are far superior at Canyon Market)
author: Boris C.

description:
This is my revised review for Canyon, upping them from 3 to 4 stars. My initial complaint was due to some pretty shoddy customer service (isn't that the issue whenever a retail business gets it wrong?), and while it's a way off perfect, they're making the right moves. Kids don't listen to their iPod on the checkout anymore, although you still have to jump around naked to get the attention of the people who 'work' behind the meat counter.

The quality of food is good and the selection is improving. The prices aren't great, but then this isn't Ralphs. All in all, heading in the right direction and Glen Park is better for these people being here.
author: Kev B.

description:
A stellar addition to the neighborhood. The selection is excellent, and the prices are pretty fair given that without Canyon Market, you'd have to get in your car and leave the neighborhood to find hormone-free meat, organic produce, herbs, and the like. (See a price comparison chart in the most recent Glen Park News for more details on how this spot compares with other markets.)

I'm not usually a sandwich person, but their sizable sandwiches are excellent -- I'm a fan of the roast turkey with pesto. The staff is always receptive to requests (they'll sell you a half sandwich, for example, even though the option isn't posted). And their sugar snap pea salad is very tasty. 

What's more, the management seems incredibly receptive to neighborhood feedback -- I've seen how the selection has changed in response to requests. 

I live close to Canyon Market and love to cook. Being able to run out of the house five minutes before a dinner party starts because I need more strawberries (which, by the way, cost less than at Whole Foods) is a gift. So happy they're here.
author: joanna p.

description:
This place is an incredible, throne of ORGASMIC ORGANIcity because the FOLKS that work here are the BEST! It is teeny tiny, but it shocked me to find such varieties of goodness, i didn't know what to make of it and then to find really sweet and helpful people; I thought I found the Shangri-la of this Glen Park gem!!!!!! When it first opened up it was not that crowded, but the secret is out and those that know to shun Wholepaychex know to come here for their goodies. 

The variety and the homemade organic pizza dough with cornmeal crust is what really got me started and it is also close to many bus lines and the BARt STATION.

It was just by accident I decided to check this place out because my friend wanted to check out a coffeeplace playing jazz nearby.

Give your grocery moolah to this place it BEAMS....GOOOOOD KARRMAA!!!! The older guy also makes his own bread and dough for pizza that you can pick up by the counter.

SOUPS tooo!!!

LOVE this place!!!!
author: miriam b.

description:
As soon as you walk through the automatic doors, you get a whiff of some mysterious odor.  I'm still trying to figure out whether it offends me, or if I'm indifferent to it.  And I still don't know what the hell I'm smelling! 

But anyway, the salad bar is always stocked with goodies - yesterday they had something new, delicious dried tomatoes in oil (and I'm NOT usually a fan of those).  

Everything is expensive, as things generally are in a frou-frou market, but if you're wiling to pay then you'll reap the benefits of organic produce, a large variety of refrigerated items and brands, and the fact that you're supporting a local business.
author: Lily E.

description:
Whole Foods wannabe. This is not a bad thing: who wouldn't want to aspire to be a Whole Foods when it means you can charge prices like that! Ka-ching!


But still better than nothing, and definitely a whole lot better than Safeway.

I fear for the cheese shop round the corner tho'.
author: bristol b.

description:
So happy to have them in the hood.  Just wished they were open later!

Everyone who works there is really nice and they have a nice balance of groceries to premade yummies.
author: Marie U.

description:
I get in my car to drive to Canyon Market rather than walk down the street to Molly Stones. Normally i only buy produce here (lots of organic and much cheaper than molly stones), but today i grabbed a baguette on the way out. It was still warm from the oven. Pretty hard to top that.

People who work there are great, and there is a lot in this fairly small store. Surprised to see so many rough reviews.
author: Grem W.

description: Came here with a friend the other day and loved the neighborhood feel of the market. Very nice market and everything in their bakery looked sooooo good. I was lucky enough to try out their pumpkin cheesecake at our girls movie night and it was so so delicious! A bit pricey but definitely worth it : ) I think I'll be back soon to try out some other yumminess!
author: Colleen M.

description:
Everything looks so beautiful and they carry some organic items not found at the big grocery stores.  But be careful when you buy prepared foods from the deli and ask to taste or try it first to check for freshness.  I wish I had today but I was too shy & didn't have the nerve with people waiting behind me.  Today  I bought Grilled Basil Prawns & when I got home & opened the container, noticed that strange smell!  Tasted one & knew it was not the seasoning or my imagination, the prawns were rotten! Eating just one was a mistake but I expected top quality & freshness at almost $20 per pound!   
Update:  I sent an email through their website and the owner got back to me right away and offered a double refund.  So I upgraded to 3 stars from 1.
Should I actually go back and ask for a refund?
author: Laurel R.

description:
I went into this market yesterday after trying the savory crepes at Higher Grounds (around the corner) that everyone raves about. I'd rate Higher Grounds 2 and this market 5 after my adventure... why? 
The food at Higher Grounds is filled with oil. That was the predominate flavor for me. Did it taste good? Yeah, but not as good as a few hundred extra calories worth of corn oil should make fried potatoes. Did I feel good after? Not at all. I love friendly neighborhood places, and if you're looking for a good cup of coffee and character, by all means, go there. Otherwise, you may want to be a bit weary of all the other glowing yelp reviews. 

The real gem of my afternoon exploration was Canyon Market. I'd driven past and always wondered how it was. For those that were disappointed, you have to go in with realistic expectations. This is not a place to do weekly shopping (unless you don't care about price and  limited variety). However, it is an amazing mecca of high-quality, healthy and gourmet items and is now officially my favorite gourmet market in SF. They have lots of hard to find items that are an absolute delight. I got: seasonal pumpkin spice soy milk (going to be my night cap through the holidays... to die for, and at 5% fat, a lot healthier than most things I could have), a fresh salad from their salad bar, bakery items (chocolate cookies and chocolate pudding... can we say "craving"?), pasta shop butternut squash ravioli, smoked chicken apple sausage, prepared red pepper broccollini and fresh bread. 

Last night I threw together the easiest, best dinner I've made in ages. We had the ravioli with just a bit of butter and fried sage leaves, along with the chicken sausage sauteed with onions and apples in white wine and I just reheated the broccollini. Now I'm sitting here eatting the salad I made for lunch.  All of their dressings are homemade, and I chose lemon parmesan. The salad bar's not as big as Whole Foods, but I'd go to this one any day and it's better than most any other I've seen in the city. 

For anyone who wants a beautiful neighborhood market that will inspire great meals, and isn't just out to fill an entire basket at value prices, go, go, go. I will be back many times. If you see someone lusting after the pine nut macaroons, and tasting olives, or trying to decide between the lemon parmesan and shallot dressings, it's me.
author: Shoshana D.

description: Very good sandwiches were enjoyed by three painfully hungover cousins in front of the Champions League final match, and they were delicious sandwiches indeed.  One of my cousins was in town from NYC and he was also impressed.  He NEVER makes any food for himself (perpetual ordering-in or eating-out NYCguy) so he has lots of manwich past experience.  Excellent, friendly service to boot.  We ordered three different sandwiches and then mixed 'em up, and all the styles I tried were tasty.  It was like sandwich roulette and everybody won.........better prices, produce, and lay-out at Good Life Market on Bernal, though.
author: Michael G.

description:
This is more or less the neighborhood version of Whole Foods. It shares a similar aesthetic and inventory, but occupies a much smaller space, and as such, it cannot compete when it comes to selection.

I'm only in the neighborhood for work and school, so I haven't done much grocery shopping there, however, their sandwich counter is awesome. I had an incredible veggie sandwich for lunch the other day, and I plan on going back as often as possible for more of these delicious creations and checking out what else they have to offer my tastebuds.

Expect to pay a buck or two more than you would at Safeway, but in the end the difference between the two is pretty evident, and I'd say worth the money.
author: Alex C.

description:
Sometimes it's great going to your cheese shop for your cheese, your bakery for some bread, the butcher for some meat, and sometimes it's just great to get that stuff in one place.  And it's even better when that place also has a great selection of organic produce, is BART accessible, and has Maltesers.

Probably one of the better grocery stores in the city.  Prices?  Well, I could probably do better than this place, but what I don't save in pennies I save in time.  Great little store.
author: Charlotte M.

description:
After going through a cupcake withdrawal from Sprinkles, I needed a cupcake and I needed one fast and cheap. When I found Canyon Market, I was so excited. Cupcakes close to home and only for $2! At that point I was like Sprinkles . . . Sprinkles, who?! 

Canyon Market is noticeably different from the rest of the neighborhood, you won't miss it. If it helps, it's a block away from the Glen Park Station. Right next to the cash registers, tempting healthy shoppers, holds the cupcakes in a box of 4 for $7.95. I ended up buying Red Velvet with Cream Cheese Frosting and Pumpkin with Cream Cheese Frosting. There was also a strawberry one and a chocolate one, but I don't remember the frostings. 

The cupcakes were meant for dessert after dinner,  but we were too full to eat them. We ended up hiding them in a purse and carrying them into the movies. By this time, the cupcakes were toppled over, with much of the frosting on the box and not on the cake. Not that it bothered me though. I really liked the Pumpkin and had a bite of the Red Velvet. They were both yummy, moist, and not too sweet. But the frosting was  ehhh. . . It was VERY soft, like gooey, and tasted too much like straight up whipped cream cheese. 

I definitely want to try this place out again, like when I want to get my calories on. Maybe next time they won't use cream cheese frosting. Either way, compared to Sprinkles' price and location, I give it one and a half thumbs up.
author: Adrianna C.

description:
I am glad I waited a while to review this place, not as long as we waited for it to open...it's a really sweet market that's finally coming around to feel like wholefoods. Only more expensive than even them.  I am happy to support a local family and business, but please, check your produce and dates on perishables. Most of things I bought were fine, and tasty. My red pepper, beautiful on the outside and moldy on the inside came as a surprise. The date on my dairy was too close for comfort.

Overall, I love the meat counter, and  even the salad bar. The store has a nice flow, and friendly staff. I'll keep coming back.
author: elena l.

description:
When I was looking for wine, specific to what my girlfriend and I enjoyed I called there after speaking with the winery.  I had the opportunity to speak with Richard, who advised he would call the distributor and call me back.  Of course I thought I wouldn't get a call at all, but sure enough, I got a call back within ten minutes.  The order of wine I wanted was going to be there the next day and I could pick it up on the way home.

I then thought it was a fluke, but nope, everyone there at the market were friendly, and the selection of items were great!  It was like a small town market in the big city.  It is really a gem and worth going to, not only for their selection but their unbelievable customer service.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Four stars!  As long as you are looking for a fancy-type grocery store and not a place to stock up on staples (this would blow your budget at Canyon Market.)  But in the realm of Whole Foods / Bi-Rite / etc Canyon Market is great.

I would step off my shuttle at Glen Park BART, run down and grab some fish or wine for dinner, and run back to the BART.  Easy and convenient.

The fourth star is for the ribeye - which was the same quality as at Bi-Rite but somehow cheaper.  By no means cheap, but cheaper is fantastic!
author: Adrienne W.

description: Very happy to have this market in the Village, despite the prices. Consistently excellent quality of all stocked items, meats, dairy, produce, bakery, and some amazingly yummy prepared foods. It is possible to find some very reasonably priced grocery items, staples, and beverages. Service and attitude has improved 120% over the past few years. You pay for the convenience, but at least you get awesomeness. I prefer to get cheese and imported jams at The Cheese Boutique around the corner. Quality and prices are comparable to Molly Stone's and cheaper than Whole Paycheck Foods.
author: Lotion M.

description: Someone listened. I was so tired of waiting by the counters while everyone behind them talked about their hair, the weather, or what their fiends were doing that I was almost ready to leave. To my surprise, they have installed bells to ring while you're waiting, more people who pay attention, and three cashiers all the time. While they still aren't stellar by any means, especially for the prices, they have gotten a lot better on customer service. It's one of the few places I can still buy raw milk and they've even made their deliveries of this better; I had a personal conversation with their dairy manager, who was friendly and personable. Thank goodness they listened to some reviews.
author: Kris S.

description:
This place is outlandishly pricey, but that's excusable since it's really more gourmet store than grocery store, and it's somehow just plain very likeable. The selection isn't extensive--especially of dry goods like crackers, cereal, and packaged foods--but what they do have is generally high-quality artisan stuff.

Highlights: nice deli counter, good bread baked in store, nice cheese and condiment selection, reasonable, if small, meat counter, nice little salad bar, huge variety of drinks, artisan chocolates and pastries you won't otherwise find in this part of town, and an in-store cafe. And the staff (which includes the owners, a husband-wife team) are unusually friendly.

There never seem to be very many people in here, even at peak hours, so I hope they have enough business to stay open.
author: Mark G.

description:
I love this place!  You can do pretty much all your grocery shopping here, and they are very gluten-free friendly.  They have frozen gf waffles, pizza crusts, and breads, 8 or 9 different kinds of gf cookies, gf cereal and grains.  I'm guessing that Whole Foods has a larger selection, but this is still quite great, especially considering the size of the store. It's so nice to be able to pick up what I need without making a special trip.  If they would just carry sorghum flour, gf rolled oats, and chebe mix, I'd be all set.  They also have lots of local and organic stuff like truly free-rang eggs (pricey!), strauss milk and butter, raw milk, spectrum shortening, and organic chard and kale.  It's just a short walk from my place, so I try to make a point to do a fair amount of my shopping here.  I do go to Manila Oriental Market for my asian foods fix, though.

Also, they've sharpened my knives before, check on ingredients, and are just generally very helpful.
author: Susan S.

description: Soups are awesome here and also great selection of cheese and wine. They have a really nice deli section and bakery has a good selection of basic goods.
author: Emily Y.

description: Down with Safeway. Canyon Market is the closest place in the neigborhood to get food of any real quality. They have great produce, meat, and even a good wine selection. They are always trying out new products, and always have something curious to try. The people working there are hip and helpfull. A little pricey, but you pay for quality and convenience, and your money is not going to stock holders worlds away. You say we pay too much for food, I say you pay too little; the "good" prices people are looking for have a hidden price for the environment and our bodies. Don't be selfish now. Keep it up CM
author: Frankie V.

description:
I am writing this review because of the AWESOME catering that Canyon Market just did for my a work party (held at my house) last night.  I called and chatted with Julie, who is AMAZING, about the menu that I wanted, a comfort food line-up, not seeing it on their regular catering menu online.  Please note again that not one item I requested was on their menu and I am calling them on Wednesday night for a Friday party.  Julie very kindly, made a quick phone call to the chef who was on his way home and promptly called back with a big "yes we can", some helpful suggestions and very good prices (I checked them against Whole Foods who was about $10 more for every single item).  Upon pick-up, the Canyon Market team helped carry everything to my car in the pouring rain, provided heating instructions (they did offer to have it heated for me, but I opted to heat it at home), little signs for every item, and they just seemed so darn appreciative for my business!  How did it taste?  Let's just say that I had to fight to keep ANY of the leftovers.  Our guests were negotiating over who got the manchego mac'n'cheese vs the pot pies.  Even people who say they detest brussel sprouts were wolfing down these ones tossed with caramelized cipollini onions and huge chunks of bacon.

It was a huge success thanks to Canyon Market!  Oh yes, and they have Strauss Milk too, so I can get my fancy milk fix =)
author: Julie H.

description: The boyfriend and I came here today for some lunch. We ordered some sandwhiches from the deli and they were amazing. I got the crabcake and he got the pastrimi and swiss. Both were delish and tasted so fresh. We also got the Humboldt Fog cheese and cracker, which was also amazing. It's a little on the pricey side but then again it is guality. They have a great selection of produce, deli, and cheese. I love this gem of a market and happy that I live within walking distance.
author: Gina P.

description:
Complainers about prices need to realize this isn't a cart-bags-of-groceries-to-your-SUV-type supermarket.  Nor is it a quickie corner convenience LOTO-mart.  The beauty of Canyon Market is that it has found that sweet spot in between -- a neighborhood grocery store with a good selection and reasonable prices.  The diversity of the deli, quality produce, fresh-baked bread and all-around upscale yet friendly atmosphere is just an added bonus, in my opinion, and the management works to constantly improve the experience.

However, if you absolutely insist on burning gas just to wait in long lines served by indifferent check-out clerks, to stock up on a week's worth of mediocre produce that mostly ends up in the compost bin, and/or have difficulty managing your time and budget, then there are alternatives to Canyon Market...
author: Danny R.

description:
GREAT grocery store (if a bit pricey)! I am so sad I moved away from Glen Park just as this place opened.

They have: lots of samples...beautiful produce....my favorite pizza in the world, America Flatbread (in the frozen section)...lots of vegetarian stuff...great homemade bread...delicious vegan pumpkin spread (much more delicious than it sounds)....etc etc
author: Kelsey E.

description:
I love this store.  It makes me wish I lived in the 50s and that it is the only store to go shopping for groceries, wine, the butcher, toiletries, anything.  It's so quaint, and nice, and small and doesn't have a lot of selections so you don't have to worry about brands because you just get what they have.  They have a really good selection of cheeses, wine, deli items, and one of those make your own salad bars.   They are a little pricey, but I just feel better buying what few items I need through out the week here, then going to some stinky old Safeway!  

Keepin it simple!
author: Sara P.

description:
It's nice to have a market so close, and the prepared foods that I've had are very good.

The prices are a bit ridiculous, however, and it makes me make sure that I've got *everything* I need to make dinner for the week when I do my shopping at other markets on the weekend so that I only have to use Canyon Market for the "oh crap I forgot" type stuff.  

Also, their fish selection is kind of lackluster.  I have a feeling they try to keep the selection down to keep it fresh because at the prices they charge I doubt they move very much of it.
author: David T.

description:
Canyon Market is a wonderful addition to Glen Park.

Pros: 
- It's a convenient and nice organic market that our area needed.
- They sell wine (some organic) and beer.
- They sell coffee in the AM, breakfast pastries, already made and made to order sandwiches, a nice salad and olive bar, place to order cuts of meat, sausage and fresh fish, nice cheese choices, and hot and cold cooked foods.
- They messed up on my sandwich order and when I called to complain, the owner got on the phone and completely rectified the entire situation.  Great customer service!
- I like the fact that they sell products of locally owned or smaller companies.

Cons:
- It's expensive.  I know you get what you pay for, but it can really be pricey.
- While I like the fact they sell local products or products from smaller companies, sometimes you just need regular old Advil or Tylenol - not some homeopathic medicine that costs $20.  I wish they could add "general" items to the store.
- Hours are limited.  They close at 8pm every night.  Seems so early to me.
author: Carol S.

description:
I LOVE THIS STORE (yes all caps!).  I live in the neighborhood so I go here all the time.  Here is a list of my favorite items at Canyon:
- cut flowers
- sandwiches from the deli
- fresh tamales in the cold section
- fresh cornmeal pizzas from the cold section (grab the tamales while you are at it and some of their homemade mole sauce near the homemade spreads behind you)
- fresh baked bread
- cupcakes
- the rotisserie chicken 

I used to think that they were a little over priced but the quality more than  justifies the price.
author: Amy F.

description: I've just moved to the neighborhood (three weeks ago) and was looking forward to the convenience of a health-conscious neighborhood grocery store. Unfortunately, Canyon Market is a disappointment. The prices are unreasonably inflated; given the quality of their products there really is no justification. So far my partner and I have purchased garlic that started sprouting in a matter of days and parmigiano reggiano that came with mold on it. Given its convenient location, I'll probably be back more than I'd like, but I plan to avoid shopping here as much as possible.
author: K M.

description: This is a great local organic market.  While it does not have the depth and breadth of offerings of a a much larger whole foods, it definitely fits my needs.  Great organic and natural offering, wine selection, and prepared foods.  When I'm running late from work and getting off of BART, its nice to have Canyon Market therefor a quick pick up of a healthy dinner.  The staff is always friendly and helpful.  I love this place and am glad it's in my neighborhood.
author: Loren S.

description:
Thank god for canyon market.  I was having friends over for dinner the other night and was running late.  I just stoped at Canyon Market on my way home and voila, everything I needed in one spot.  Fresh bread, cheese, salad fixins, and yum, dessert.

The neighborhood is better off with the addition of Canyon Market !
author: Ava M.

description: Dont get me wrong this place is great when one lives in the area, but be warned some items are far more expensive than that of whole foods. Their produce is good and the salad bar is awesome. They also have a good beer and alcohol selection. The deli is great!
author: J B.

description:
its like a small town market. one that is is stocked and run by good country people with small town values, but don't think the products are quiet right and the salmon was $22 a pound. Between Cheese Boutique and Buddy's, not much has been added to the neighborhood.

But the salad bar is great, and the service is nice. The carry La Fin du Monde for far less that Whole Foods. 

the sandwiches are great.
author: Joe D.

description:
I love this place. 

I'm here just about every day. They have everything you need in a compact, easy to shop space. Great home made bread, organic everything, good coffee bar,  wonderful prepared foods, and the best mole in the city (check out the little home made offerings by the cheese area - they make amazing stuff!) The staff is always friendly and helpful.

Sure, I spend a fortune there, but it's cheaper than going out.
author: E B.

description: This place is OK but let me just say two words -- or should i say one hyphenated Bi-Rite, go there now. What Canyon wishes it could be.
author: Marlene E.

description: Amazing salad bar and sandwiches, great service and variety, amazing bread.  I love the focus on local and organic.  The only complaints are the wine section (there are limited moderately priced, good wines) and the cheese section sometimes has outdated cheeses (be sure to check your labels).  I love shopping here and do so daily.  They are also really good about integrating customer feedback.  I highly recommend this place.
author: Brianne O.

description:
I want to like this store. I really do.  I want to support local, family-owned grocers.  I want to walk to my local store.  I want to get to know the folks who work behind the counters.  I really do.  But I feel a little violated every time I buy something there.  Don't get my wrong.  I am willing to play for small, independent stores.  I am willing to overlook higher costs in return for quality and friendly service.  And I always have done this at all of the other local, family owned stores I have shopped at.  But this store is on the other side of whatever imaginary line I have created for myself.   I will gladly pay the 3x markup for the super fancy imported tuna from Italy.  But come on. $7 for a box of cereal?  $5 for a box of pasta?   

I also wrote the store an email and gave them some feedback.  (Love their meat counter and prices are good.  Lower the prices of every day stuff, and you'll get a whole lot more customers).  And they never wrote me back.  :-(
author: Mel C.

description: Super helpful courteous staff.  Great wine & beer selection.  Best veggies you can get aside from a Farmer's Market and my favorite meat counter.
author: Kelley F.

description: I stopped by this little market while waiting for the bus, so BF and I decided to pick up some food for dinner. There is a great salad bar, a great list of organic fruits and vegetables. I love their prepared deli section.  It took me awhile to figure out what to get.  We finally picked up a rotisserie chicken, some organic crackers and cheese.  BTW, there is a great selection of cheeses. I also love their selection of cracker/chip dips and ready to cook pasta/sauces. The only thing is it's a little pricey, but otherwise a great neighborhood grocery store.
author: Jenny W.

description: I used to have a part time job in Glen Park and that's when I first discovered Canyon Market. What keeps me coming back long after I left that job is the pre-made food. They add something unique to every dish they make. I was prompted to write this review after having their butternut squash lasagna for lunch today, cheesy, creamy goodness! Also, the salad bar is awesome, one of the freshest in the city!
author: Sarah B.

description: I have been here 3 times. At first I was stoked. Great looking deli counter. Good stock of quality items. After eating from the deli counter, I will not do it again. The counter food is very expensive, and not good quality. The last stuff I bought I wanted to throw away, but ate it anyway because I spent so much. They have a good stock of dry goods, albeit expensive. The produce is not very thorough, and it is expensive. This will be an occasional market for me. Not the weekly I was hoping for since I just moved to the neighborhood.
author: sadie r.

description: If you live in Glen Park this is really the most convenient option for something gourmet or organic. The staff is always helpful and friendly. It's a small market so you can't always find everything you need. However, the have a great produce section and a wonderful selection of pre-made gourmet entrees, sides and desserts. Definitely on the expensive side of the grocery scale, but in fairness it's all high quality ingredients.
author: Marissa P.

description: I miss living in Glen Park! and Canyon Market is one of the things I miss the most. Now I live in SOMA right by a Whole Foods... but it's not the same.  What makes Canyon so much better?  Maybe it's the fresh baked bred (baked daily in the store), or the to die for caramelized Brussels sprouts or calamari salad in their deli case.  Maybe it's their special secret recipe rice pudding, or any number of specialty foods that are made in house in small batches and taste like they are made with love.  This place has the feel of a small town, high end grocery store... it just feels friendly.  Yes the selection is somewhat limited, and I will not argue with the fact that it is a but pricey, but they have really good stuff you can't find anywhere else (like their salami with fennel seeds in it, which my mom requests any time she hosts a party).
author: Liz A.

description: I hate this place.  Everything is over priced, the workers are all snobby, the produce isn't fresh, and the selection blows.  The only reason this place stays in business is because its right by the bart station.
author: Caleb R.

description: So, really a four star place but I BELIEVE that they will soon become five stars.  The neighborhood needs this, I need this, so in my gut I know they are getting their act together. So far, great produce, deli and flowers.  Everything else seems to be coming together so I am hoping this will be the Bi-Rite of Glen Park.  They have sandwich specials every day, but my favorite is their hot roast beef, havarti cheese, roasted red peppers and grainy mustard on ciabatta.  Pair that with salt and pepper kettle chips and it's a good day.
author: Stacy R.

description: I first discovered this market not long after it opened and have visited numerous times. I noticed the salad and soup bar of course but have to be very cautious due to food allergies(celiac disease). At the time nothing was labeled to indicate ingredients, and the soups required asking if anyone knew ingredients. I thought the market cute and continued to visit and shop. I looked at the website which provided an e-mail address and inquired about the prospect of clearly labeling the food bar selections but no reply. On a later visit I asked for the business card of the owners who I was told were not available, and as the card gave both of their e-mail addresses, i sent a message quite congenially inquiring about the issue of the labeling, and complimentary about the store. I never received a reply. Today i went in hoping I might be able to get something safe to eat, and happened to inquire of none other than the owner. She suggested that the executive chef would come out to assist. He did so, and was a kind gent who then went thru the numerous selections, and as we spoke pulled various signs that were incorrect. Some indicated gluten where he was confident there was none, others not indicating there was in instances where he knew they wasHe pulled the written recipes for each. As I selected several things on his assurance, he offered two additional soups that were not out yet. He suggested vegetable minestrone, but when I queried him he realized, yes, it had pasta, but he assured me the turkey and rice  soup would be perfect.I ordered a pint and decided to eat at their small seating area inside. As I ate the soup, i realized with my fourth spoonful that the soup was full of white pasta, not rice.I was shocked, and returned to the deli counter and sought him out, he was confused by it....I asked him to have the owner come out as I appreciated his sincerity but it was clear she needed to know the depth of the problem there. I was told she wass busy. I asked for someone who could take the unconsumed food and refund my money. A shift supervisor came out who began to understand the problem the second or third time I explained it. He expressed regrets several times,,,I requested he ask the owner whom I had met earlier to phone me, he simply took my # and said 'someone' would be in touch. Bottom line, celiac disease is not a food preference, it's a serious G.I. allergy......the consequences of consuming gluten for celiacs is serious. I did not appreciate the chaotic way my needs were  falsely addressed. I normally shop at Real Foods, a larger family owned business, where the owner returns her customer's e-mails and phone calls! I will not return to Canyon Market.
author: ken k.

description: Canyon Market is a great addition to Glen Park. It's owned and run by a very friendly couple and they have a great selection for such a small market. The main thing I go for is the locally produced Strauss Dairy milk - the best I have come across in the US! The prices are relatively high - but I'd much rather give my money to a neighbor than a corporation from Pleasanton or Austin.
author: Tony H.

description: Very cute local high end grocer, though definitely over priced.  If you want something specific, like great cheeses, homemade bread or the likes you can definitely find it here.
author: Sarah B.

description: Upping my original rating to the full five stars. Recently moved back to the neighborhood and have rediscovered Canyon Market. The deli here is flat-out awesome. Great sandwiches and tasty prepared food. Yes, it's still expensive, but it's not really for your everyday grocery shopping needs. Love having it in the neighborhood.
author: Wendy G.

description: What couldnt you love about this adorable market? The staff is super friendly, knowledgable, and outgoing. The true gem of the store is the cheese selection! The cheeses are reasonably priced, varied in textures as well as tastes, and everything can be cut down to order. Now thats my idea of an amazing cheese shopping experience.
author: J J.

description: I come here to get lunch during work about once every few weeks.  I love getting a half pint of soup and  a small salad from the salad bar.  The soup is really fresh and has that homemade quality.  The salad bar has so much good stuff in it, it's hard to choose.  All of the homemade salads and dips they sell are also really good, and overall it's just a great little market.  Super friendly staff and a great neighborhood spot!
author: Karen B.

description: I love their chicken strips and their delicious cupcakes.
author: Cristian G.

description:
this place is the local mom and pop whole foods. they carry high-end items and yes they are a little pricey. 
their meats and veggies are sustainable. they carry yummy treats you can't find anywhere else.
their fresh salad bar is decent. there's a good selection of homemade dressing, fresh veggies and various pre-made pastas.
they're always nice and friendly. there's a couple of tables outside to sit and enjoy lunch.
author: Lola L.

description: Went in here the other day bought some stuff. i would say its pretty pricey here and the Asian chick running the cash register was mean and needs an attitude check.
author: Alyssa J.

description: I was overjoyed when a cute, organic market opened in my neighborhood. That was before I went there. Although the selection is decent, I've bought rotten food here twice. Once it was yogurt past its prime, and another time it was rotten dolmas from the (not so) fresh bar. And the staff can be downright rude. One morning, after waiting at the unmanned coffee bar for a few minutes, I asked one of the women at the checkout if the coffee bar was open, and she just shrugged, rolled her eyes, and told me it's not her section. Uh, thanks for being so helpful! So until I'm confident that the food won't make me ill and the staff learns some basic customer service skills, I'll keep going to Good Life and Bi-Rite.
author: Jen R.

description:
I read so many reviews and also heard from people that this place is GREAT.... however, I was very diappointed when I walked in there.  Now I live in the neighborhood, but I only buy anything if I am desparate.  I rather go to Whole Foods.
The other day, I found a pack of Sushi (Tuna?) they were selling that looked very bad --- it seemed that if anyone tries that sushi, he would get sick.... it was not very fresh.
Everything seems over-priced, too.
author: Miinno N.

description:
Bad meats! I've always had a sketchy feeling about the meat in this low-turnover market (fish, pork, and beef all looking old) and was finally proven right when I got a package of ground beef which reeked of a brackish slough. Do yourself a favor and go to the Safeway up the block. Packaged, edible beef beats this "butcher counter" all the way.

Good bakery though.
author: Mizz N.

description: This market isn't really that big and it carries a so-so selection of products . They have a salad bar where you can make your own salad . They sell frozen foods , personal care products (not much) , gluten-free foods (some) , meats , fish , beverages , cheese , etc. I really like their cheese section . They have fresh chunks of cheese of all sizes ! Seriously .. there's some chunks that are as big as my head ! LOL . I also really like their beverage selection .. it's very interesting .
author: Eileen L.

description: It ain't perfect, but it's pretty dang good.  Good sandwiches too!
author: Tom L.

description: Decent enough neighborhood grocer. Overripe fruit, brown lettuce, good specialty food selection, and a great deli counter.  But the check-out experience is horrible!  Disinterested cashiers who barely know how to have a polite conversation.  And if you want customers to line-up to check-out, then wait to be called to a cashier, then PUT UP A SIGN!  And it slows down check-out.  Stupid!
author: Eric U.

description: I haven't bought anything there except for a few mangoes and a cream soda, but I gotta tell ya...I'd buy mangoes for a buck-fifty each any day from this place.  Each one I've eaten was perfectly ripe and yummy.  Magic I tell ya...magic.
author: Duckie A.

description: The produce is sometimes a little past the point it should be on the shelf, but I love the salad bar.  They also carry some things that I used to find only at Oakville Grocery at Stanford Shopping Center (that location is closed, and I'm never up north to go to the other locay), like the black diamond cheddar spread (5 stars) and the smoked chicken spread (also 5 stars).  Everything here is way overpriced, more than Whole Foods, but for the things I can't find elsewhere I really like this place.  It's also on my way home so that salad bar comes in handy a few times a week.  It's a small market, limited in options for any given category, but they've got the bases covered.
author: Emily T.

description:
D'OH!   I did it again, damnit!  

Went in for breakfast staples (local organic milk, half and half, yoghurt and such) and walked out with another  whopper of a bill.  Perhaps it was the many,  items I couldn't pass up, like guac, salsa and thick tortilla chips, the "Sandwich of the Day", the 70% cocoa chocolate bar, etc, etc, etc...

This little market is a gauntlet of not-to-pass-up goodies.  If you're an impulse buyer, like me, be careful stepping foot into this little Glen Park pit of temptation.  

Why?  Because they stock high-priced and from what I've experienced so far, very boutique and high quality food and goods that are difficult not to try.  You have to fight the impulse to grab this or that  as you make your way towards  the friendly cashier staff.

My brother and sister-in-law, both Berliner Germans, who went to Canyon Market  (DAILY...for 6days straight) to buy whatever, really loved it.  They were extremely  impressed with the organic fruits and vegetables.  The huge seasonal bins of impressive and varied organic heirloom tomatoes nearly brought them to their knees.  Caprese Salad, for days, anyone? 

Beyond that, Canyon Market has a very impressive salad bar, a small but nice selection of high-end liquors and a very good selection of wines and import beers.  The meats always look tasty and the seafood looks to be fresh, and ,whenever possible, local.  Their cheese section is small,  but that may be a nod to the local nearby cheese shop. (Perhaps Canyon is being a good neighbor to other established nearby businesses?)  The prepared food section looks pretty darn amazing although I haven't sampled any yet.  The in-house bakery does well also, seeminly going so far as not overlapping baked goods featured at the nearby Destination Bakery.

If you're a frequent Safeway or Lucky's shopper you'll probably run screaming because of the prices.  If you live nearby and are used to buying high quality, often local and organic food and goods (whatever the price) you may end up being a fan.
author: Ian N.

description: A nice little market that is nice change from a supermarket. However this place is pricey. They have some stuff you cant find in a supermarket so that was nice.
author: Leon C.

description: I stopped in here on my way home from pilates at kiki-yo. This is a cute small wholefoods type store. I enjoyed browsing through it and seeing all the new, weird foods. A lot of the stuff looked tasty, but I was trying to not spend a lot (stores like this are always a lot of $) and also could only carry home a couple things that I needed on the bart and bus so... the cashier was very friendly, and it seemed very neighborhoodly. If I lived around here, I'd probably come every once in a while to pick up something interesting and healthy to eat.
author: Merredith L.
