description: I knocked them down a star because their groceries are just so expensive. But they would get 5 stars for their bakery alone. They have fresh bread coming out all day long and the best baked desserts. We always buy the linzer torte.  Being made of ground almonds and raspberry jam, it is a dessert version of a PBJ sandwich, so I think you can eat it in place of lunch. I was a bit worried it wouldn't pass muster when I fed it to a German lady who came to my house for tea, but she told me that if she lived in the neighborhood, she would stop baking and buy her pastries at Canyon Market!
author: dm S.

description: They make their own bread!  It isn't nearly as good as Acme Bread, though.  Still, housemade bread is great to have in the neighborhood.  Their pumpkin seed pate is vegan and super tasty; it's probably a seasonal item, but I'd eat it year round.  The market, overpriced though it may be,  is a great addition to Glen Park; what upscale neighborhood market isn't overpriced?  It is expected and, as such, isn't bothersome.
author: Lisa A.

description: Canyon Market is basically Whole Food lite. Great products if you can afford it. They have a really great vegetable and cheese sandwich, you don't miss the meat at all. I took a few stars off though because their customer service can use some improvement. I've seen the cashier and the deli lady be rude to customers including yours truly. I won't be making any special trips to go there, but if I'm in the neighborhood their sandwiches are enough to lure me back in.
author: Kara P.

description:
yeah, it's a bit pricey. but SOOOOOO much better than supporting mollie stone's up the hill. at least canyon market has more than five choices for organic produce (much more so). 

produce and store-made products are definitely where you should stick while shopping here. the fresh baked bread is all awesome.
their rice pudding & chocolate pudding...yeah.
good selection of cheeses.
GREAT veggie sandwich (get it made fresh, not out of the refrigerator case).
they have a perfect variety of fancy treats up by the register (ahem, vosges chocolate bars).
salad bar = raises the bar.
coffee bar...not so much (burnt soy latte, never been back). 
good case of fake frozen meat stuffs.

i can't really see myself doing a shopping cart load here (i save that for rainbow) but for spur of the moment neighborhood necessities this place has me.


but, dave. s. (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=XgvuVgykFfwFBbPe1VGU4w) is kind of right. the customer service at the register (i've always had good service at the deli counter) is snotty. but i chalk it up to the majority of the clerks up there with no smiles, no greetings and bratty attitude having full blown cases of female teenage angst.
author: Elle C.

description: Without Canyon Market, I'd be leaving the neighborhood a lot more than I do currently.  Everything is super expensive, but fresh and yummy.  And the time savings are almost worth the prices.  Kudos to them for staying open during power outages.
author: Aaron D.

description: Since my original review, they have adjusted their prices (a bit). Make no mistake, its not a cheap corner grocery but the emphasis on organic and sustainably produced goods should be considered and the fact that they are not a chain adds to the appeal. You may not be able to afford their steaks and their prepared dinners, but they have a great organic produce section that everyone can afford... not to mention the fact that everyone will all benefit when consumers support local growers and merchants who refuse to allow Monsanto to poison our products and our land.
author: Chance E.

description: I went in and was kinda disappointed.  It was kinda small and I just wanted a few things to eat...but the selection didn't seem to be that great.  I got some salami, some tamales made with butternut squash and some chocolate pudding...and whoa...delicious.  Odd choices I know, but everything tasted so much better then anything I've purchased at Mollie Stones or Bristol Farms.  Just plain good.  I'm going to go back here though now when I feel the need to spend more money then necessary on organic foods.  They lose one point because the girl at the checkstand was giving off a super bad vibe.
author: Katie H.

description: richard the owner, is super generous with local filmmakers. especially poor desperados like myself who call him a few days before the shoot begging for scraps b/c our PM flaked on us. Unlike other folks who rile  you for "such late notice", he understands the flake factor and totally helped us out w/ food. thanks richard!!
author: shanestar h.

description: I think this place is new, but I was out for a burrito at La Corneta and I saw this market had opened.  I came back the next day and got a really good pannini.  The pre-made food, flowers and produce looks really good as well it seems like they make alot of the pre-made food themselves.  It's about time that Glen Park finally had a good grocery store.
author: PaT F.

description: amazing sandwiches! large and reasonably priced, but mostly just YUMMY! great deli section. great salad bar. great marinated tofu. yum.... it is pricey but it is good food.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Pros- close to my house, support local farmers, healthy, good deli, range of gluten free desserts, salad bar
Cons- expenisve, bad service...
A few weeks ago my sister and I stopped off in the morning to get bagels. We parked right in front, assuming it would be a quick experience. Were we wrong! I stood in front of the coffee area for a good 2 minutes before someone even knew I was there. Then someone walked over to me, continued past me and started cleaning the coffee machine and wiping down the counters as I clearly stood right there waiting to order. When I said excuse me she turned around and acted as though I was causing her a problem. I told them I'd like to order two bagels toasted with cream cheese. I told her I was going to go get a juice and asked if I could pay for everything together and she said no! I then went and got my juice, bought it at the regular cash register area, went back over to the coffee area and payed for my bagels seperately. The woman ringing me up didn't ever ask if I wanted cash back, when I told her I did want cash back she mumbled something letting me know it was too late. Needless to say, I was a little frusterated. I was giving them service and everything seemed to be a problem to this woman who was "helping" me. I am not the type of customer who complains about little things, but I was only trying to support my neighborhood businesses and I was treated as though I was causing a problem. My sister and I will be getting bagels from the cafe accross the street from now on.
author: Joe B.

description: For a general neighborhood market, Canyon is pretty top-notch.  Mind you, you'll be paying slightly higher prices, but not much more than anywhere else... and not more than Whole Wallet.  The quality is always great, though because of the size of the market, you have just slightly fewer options.  I haven't found that to be a bad thing, however, as I always find what I'm looking for.  Their employees are friendly and helpful, and I can blame Canyon Market for my longstanding addiction to thin-sliced salami and dill Havarti.  Also, their croutons are the best in the city.
author: Robert P.

description: i love this place cuz its right next to the library and across from the taqueria, and they have lots of vegan friendly products, good wine, good produce.  yes its pricy and one of those places that thrive in up and coming hoods (ie gentrified) and can get away with charging lots of money for small things but they have outside seating and pre-made stuff inside. sort of like a mini-rainbow without all of the hassle of rainbow.  plus their coffee bar RULES. soy caramel latte for $2.85? oh hell yeah!
author: Kat R.

description:
I'm not going to weigh in on prices, as I've no idea what the financial guts of this operation are except to know the rent being asked on this building was crazy. But in truth, that's my one star off, because I'd love to be able to walk or bike to this healthy, organic-y, green-thinking, family owned neighborhood grocer's for all my groceries and never hit Safeway again in my life. Alas.

What I do want to comment on are the staff members who go out of their way to remember your coffee order (Sharon), your sandwich order (Barrett) and pretty much everything else about you (Kirsten). The owners, Richard and Janet, will also go quite out of their way for you, have ordered anything I've ever asked about, and were kind enough to gather my phoned in grocery order for me the other day when I had a sick dog with me.  Good old fashioned neighborhood service, right?

But it goes even beyond that - this morning I arrived at the coffee bar just in time to realize that I'd forgotten my coffee cup, which I'm religious about bringing so as not to use the paper ones. Sharon jokingly asked where my mug was and I must have made a grumpy face because as I went to pay I realized she had charged me the bring-your-own discount price even though I was without my trusty mug. That was awfully nice, but then I went to pay and noticed my car key was missing from my bag. I must have looked a little panicked because she came out from behind the counter and helped me look through my bag.  Literally held my books and phone and etc, while encouraging me to take everything out of the bag, while she looked around the counter and floor. No key. So Sharon took down my phone # in case anyone turned in the key. 

The key turned up later at the Glen Park BART station and when I called to tell them, they were all very relieved. Sometimes I don't get this much attention from my friends!

This is just a hands down ridiculously great neighborly way of being, and it makes this shop a real boon to Glen Park.
author: Elyse N.

description: I really like this little market.  When it opened after a long period of construction (after the other grocery store in that location burned down in a fire), I had high hopes. And they haven't disappointed.  All of their produce is organic, which is great.  And their deli has some wonderful items.  The salad bar has a lot of variety and the soups are very good.  They carry my preferred kombuchas as well and they are right on my way home from BART!  And the staff is very friendly and helpful.  All in all, a great neighborhood store!
author: Paula O.

description:
Update: They are really packed full of amazing products in their back shelves. They added a vinegar tasting section that was super helpful in finding a vinegar.  (Originally, I had said that they didn't have enough variety in their dry goods section.)

I wrote them a note, asking if they could please stock organic Galia melon. The next time I went in, there was a big basket of them. Thank you, The Management! 

They are very quick to respond to customers. So, if there is something you would like them to stock....just let them know.

The neighborhood shoppers have noted that the market is expensive. I heard through the grapevine that the owner has noted this complaint and lowered some of the prices.  I think that at least the staples are now more comparable to other stores. Still, I cannot afford any of their ready made food. Too bad  - it looks really yummy. But, I go almost daily to pick up a little something for my family of 4 since it is on my route to and from home. I usually get the very basics... milk, eggs, bread, yogurt, vegetables, fruit, tortillas, a can of black beans, etc. A bag of the simplest groceries costs me about $30. All organic and fresh.  If I throw a few items in...like specialty pickles or maybe something from their deli like their yummy smoked chicken spread...or gather up ingredients for a more complicated meal....each grocery bag becomes about $50. For us, that's a lot. 

In sum, the prepared foods behind the glass are typically expensive. But, their salad bar and soup bar is very reasonable.
author: Jennifer F.

description: prices are pretty high the selection is so-so. What I like is that it's open at 7:30 and I can get coffee on a saturday or sunday yay!
author: Princess P.

description: This is a great little store. I am a block or two away, so it is very convenient to pick up some quick things. It is a bit pricey, but they have a big selection of organic and natural foods. I usually come in for some fresh fruits or veggies or when I'm out of milk, But what really sold me on this place is the TELEME!! I love teleme cheese, it is creamy and yummy and they sell it here!
author: Kelly N.

description: I remember the old Diamond Super that burned down. Wow, that place was sad, except for the meat market, which rocked. Now, I have been watching the new Market get their act together. I can say the place is solid. Clean, great selection. The prepared foods are delicious. Best of all is the fresh, fresh organic produce. If you are a foodie, like me, this is your house. The prices aren't Costco or TJ's. Wait, you don't have to drive, burn carbon: It is local. What is your time and gas worth and are you willing to put it where your mouth is? In this case, you get to put it in your mouth. Fresh baked bread and cut flowers? Count me in.
author: Steve G.

description:
I didn't know it was possible to fuck up a cheese sandwich but I was wrong.  VERY WRONG.  I went to this place a couple times before to get coffee because it is on my way to the BART station.  I was not impressed with the coffee or their service but I noticed they had a deli so I wanted to test it one day.  SO... today 2/27/07 at about 9:25am I ordered a cheese sandwich w/everything(I love them).  Now the lady at the counter asked "are you sure you just want a cheese sandwich" and I said "definitely."  Maybe it was a mis-communication error on my part but I thought I was clear so the bitch throws a wrapped sandwich at me and does not respond to my thank you.  When I unwrapped the fucking thing on my lunch break it was like 2 million Hitler's flipping me off and pissing on my face while chuckling.  My Op Supervisor wanted to take a camera photo of it: cheddar cheese between two pieces of SLICED wheat bread = $5.25 with out even fucking mustard.  FUCK!!!!!!!  Like I said, maybe I was not clear but I've been to other delis where you don't have to ask them for veggies and condiments, ITS EXPECTED.  I had a gut feeling  when she originally threw it at me that it was fucked up BUT I gave her the benefit of the doubt.  BIG MISTAKE.

CONCLUSION: I don't even think the good beer selection will bring me back here since it WILL be overpriced and I can look forward to them being fucking shit fuckers to me.  "I am a grown man and can eat a cheese sandwich if I want to."
author: ray M.

description: It a pricey place, but a welcome change from the ghetto Safeway on Monterey.   I think Canyon Ranch is still working out the kinks, but the cheese selection is amazing (they would do well to write a few more descriptions about it).   The fresh food looks/tastes delish and they have CIAO BELLA gelato - what more could you ask for.  It's certainly not a place where someone would do the "weekly shopping" it's just to pricey, but for special occassions or when you're in a pinch it's nice to have it in the neighborhood.   Now will someone tell me what the hell an Eggettes is?
author: Steven J.

description: Canyon Market is the best.   I am there almost every day.  Really.  I missed a few weeks when I gave birth and I pined for it.  Where else can I truly walk or use transit to buy all my staples:  fresh raw milk (also two kinds of organic milk), pastured eggs, 100% grass-fed beef, coconut ice cream, organic veggies, fresh-baked bread, emphasis on locally grown food.  Yes, I admit, I have a comparatively expensive grocery bill.  But damn, we  eat well.   (As an editorial aside, why do we value cheap food?  Food is the fuel for our lives, and we get what we pay for.)  As an added plus, one of the owners always tells me how cute my baby is.  How could I not love Canyon Market?
author: Chris P.

description: I live nearby but seldom go in here.  They have a nice range of sandwiches, but when I went to get one at 6:30 at night when there was hardly anyone in the store, they told me I had to wait half an hour for my sandwich.  I did, and it was pretty good, but this isn't Ike's and that seems like a long time to me.  But the sandwich was good, a spiced pork and cheese with carmelized onions on fluffy ciabatta.  It was just about the right size and reasonably priced.  I'd go back, but only if I had the time to wait around.
author: Jeremy G.

description: glad i found this place as its close to home and has all the A+ stock you will find at Rainbow and Whole Foods downtown .. but the prices are also way higher then most other stores like it .... but its close .. so I will go !
author: Micah W.

description: I really like shopping in this grocery store, they have good produce, good meat, and a good salad bar.  The atmosphere is clean and friendly and makes me want to hang out here.  Also a good coffee bar.
author: Jimmy C.

description: This is a nice little neighbourhood grocery store.  The visual merchandising is good; and yet I can see many more products there.  I can also see a larger more coherent wine assortment.  I do like the prepared foods and cheese selections.  The vegetable were beautifully displayed.  They bake some of the goods and that makes for such an appealing draw.  I think they could drill down for more emerging brands to set itself apart from other grocers.  All in all not a pretty good local market.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: I just discovered this little market last night.  Canyon Market reminds me of a miniature Whole Foods (in the same way that Bi-Rite does).  They have a fair selection of fresh and beautiful produce and a good selection of gourmet chocolates.  They also have a small bakery, a deli, and a salad/prepared foods bar.  It's not cheap, but markets with an emphasis on health foods/organic produce rarely are.  What will bring me back, though, are the Peasant Pies (I usually get them at Rainbow, which is not as conveniently located near a BART station) and the Claiborne and Churchill gerwurstruminer (too bad they don't have the Edna Valley pinot noir or Orange Muscat).
author: Grace W.

description: Fantastic morning coffee....Love the earl grey tea shortbread and those things that look like giant cardamon biscotti. So-So organic fruit.
author: Bleep S.

description: I was told that the cupcakes here are most delicious for $1.75, so I came here to try it.  There was only 1 left, but I got it anyway.  There was a bit too much cream on top, but the cake was not bad.  One of the guys there suggested the cheesecake and said it was really good.  so i bought that too.  The cheesecake was not bad at all.  At $3.00, it is extremely affordable.  For such a small specialty market, the prices are so affordable.  I will come back and try the cobbler.  Most of their baked goods sell out fast, so come early.
author: AhLin C.

description: I stumbled across this little place shortly after the new library opened in GP and boy am I glad I did ;) They have a nice selection of wine and chocolates (they'll gift pack if you ask them to do so) and also their frozen goods and butcher counter/bakery have great selections at good prices. This isn't just a place to stop-in to grab a few sundries to hold you over until that monthly Costco trip--it's an honest-to-goodness place to buy you're weekly groceries. The focaccia, home made chicken tortilla soup, fresh baked bread, and Amy's brand products are my favourites. All can be found here for decent prices. Ohhh..and I love their Salad bar. *grin*
author: Christian D.

description: A new market on Diamond in Glen Park.  Finally something has gone into the burnt out shell of the old Diamond market.  This place is a small Andronico's/Whole Foods type market. They have food items I can't find anywhere nearby. It saves a schlep across town. Nice little espresso bar rounds out the experience. Nice produce, ready-to-eat foods and gourmet selections. Pricey, of course. Not the place to do all your shopping unless you have money to burn. But great for specialty items and supplementals.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Even though it looks small, the selection inside is pretty diverse.  I wouldn't go so far as to say it's an affordable kind of place, but my  "indulgence" of choice is organic food.  I even found flavored tuna from Australia on sale, have no idea if it's worth it, but it's tasty and healthy.
author: brenda b.

description: Canyon does trend toward high-end items, but that's only because they know their clientele. They have a wonderful produce section (especially in summer, when their stock is laden with local items), great meats, sustainable fish, really tasty deli and dessert items, and plenty of staples -- mostly at reasonable prices (given that this is a high-end SF grocery store). Their salad bar is one of the best I've ever seen, with lots of homemade dressings, and they even make their own wine -- which is yummy, by the way.
author: Beth W.

description: so i walk to the glen park bart station almost every morning and stop by here to grab a cup of my usual vanilla americano, i haven't shopped here for groceries but i have to admit their coffee is a pretty good waker-upper! the service at the coffee corner however is oddly unpleasant well its usually the same person all the time. other then that it does the job in serving my coffee the way i want but not the service id like at 7am in the morning =]
author: Nancy K.

description: It's great to finally have a market in Glen Park! This place is pretty pricey, but I don't think that's surprising for a small, village market... you pay for convenience.  At least we can now get some fresh, organic produce, and they have a nice (albeit small) selection of wine, homeopathic remedies, cheeses, and even some bulk food.  I do think it'll grow into a great neighborhood spot, especially if it's true that the owners are committed to keeping prices somewhat reasonable and responding to customer feedback--which they say they are.  Go Glen Park!
author: Caroline G.

description: A food market that 's a block away from the Glen Park BART station, that  has several buses stopping right outside, that  I can walk to from my home, that sells organic meat, fish, veggies, fresh and dried fruit, prepared food, soup and salad bar, bulk and packaged grains and pasta, nuts, seeds, wine and beer, cheese, fresh bread baked daily on the prem, gorgeous fresh flowers, and lots, lots more.....what's not to love?  Oh, I know.  The prices.  Well, you can always hop in your car and catch the bargains at Safeway or Costco, or get vac-packed everything at Trader Joe's (don't forget to fill the gas tank on your way home).
author: Carolyn S.

description: This market has seen me hung over and funky, and has never once made me feel unwelcome.  The guys in the deli are all super sweet and offer suggestions on how to cook the meat if you ask (as a novice like myself does, often), and although the prices are higher than some places, the food is better than most places. you get what you pay for, people.  stop complaining.
author: jamie m.

description: Local grocery store. Great quality and variety of foods. Much better than any Safeway.
author: John W.

description: Three and a half stars, really.  I'm holding out hope for these guys because I'm glad to see them in the neighborhood.  Prices are a little high and the staff is a little unpolished but the produce and meat/seafood are good.  Staying open a little later at night would also help increase traffic.  I've come by for dinner supplies at 7:30pm and they have been closed.  Fingers crossed for improvement.  Hopefully they can steal some business from Diamond Heights Safeway (yuck.)
author: Monkeyfaced E.

description: Not yet a perfect market, but it has enough to keep me coming back there over and over. The best features are: 1) fantastic baker - really very special, especially the cakes   2) great prepared foods - including some of the best rotisserie chicken and to-die-for-perfect pesto pasta salad 3) some hard-to-find brands, like Latini pasta . The biggest negative is very unreliable produce. They are also trying little by little to upgrade their wine section to make it a truly interesting and personal selection, even though it is at the end of the day  a food market, and so they still need to carry a fair amount of relatively generic stuff at low price points.
author: Stephen B.

description: If you're one of those people that enjoys spending time just walking through the market this one is for you.  This a beautiful looking market, always a pleasure to walk through the aisles and see what they have.  They do have some interesting things here too.  They carry a wide variety of beer, liquor, and wine (one of which is their own brand) that matches up with markets like Andronico's.  There are also lots of organic food options, a nice deli/meat/seafood area and a coffee bar.  The seafood here always looks amazing.  The coffee bar opens an hour earlier than any of the other cafes on the street too.  Like Trader Joes they never have anything on sale but unlike Trader Joes everything here is on the pricey side.  Overall I really like this market.  I would not come here to do my regular shopping but I love coming here just to take a peek.
author: Matt P.

description: not bad. it was really balmy yesterday and i was starving between class and work. good job on the bottled kombucha selection, canyon market! lots of things to choose from, delicious broccoli cheddar soup, and some trail mix to go. nice to sit outside, too. glen park is a fun place to people watch. pricey, but i'm glad you're there. :)
author: bex m.

description: just really check out what you a buying....lots of 'old' stuff  dead lettuce's and cheese and slimy fish.  way over priced compared to whole 'paycheck'   great staff  !!!  come on guys... just through out half the cheese i bought yesterday
author: alexander k.

description: I visited this store for the first time when I went to the dedication of the new Glen Park Library on Oct. 13, 2007. I was delighted and surprised -- this neighborhood really needed a grocery like this. The closest large grocery store used to be the Safeway at the top of the hill in the Diamond Heights Shopping Center, and now Glen Park has its own natural foods store with a really good selection. Yes, a bit pricey, sort of like a mini-Whole Foods, but worth it, especially if you live nearby, like organics, and want convenience -- at last a natural foods store right there in the neighborhood. There's a butcher, baked goods, a deli, wines and cheeses -- the same type of things I'm used to picking up at Whole Foods. So next time I'm hiking around Glen Canyon I can stop by and pick up dinner when I'm done. It's very convenient to the Glen Park Metro and BART stations.
author: Galomorro H.

description: Glen Park needed a grocery store after Diamond Super burned down years ago and now we have it.   I'm pretty selective about what I buy there because it is pricey and I mostly go for the meat, fish, prepared salads, or when i need one or two items.  Downside for me is the lack of parking; I'd probably go there more often if it was easier to park. But then, I'd probably use more of the businesses in Glen Park if there was more parking.  Would be nice if they had a delivery service for those of us who are getting up there in years!
author: suzanne l.

description: This place has that organic trend thing going on and follows the trend with their prices. Although their goods are pricey, they're very tasty and are complemented well with the general atmosphere.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Conveniently located?  Yep, if you live in Glen Park.

Parking?  Street --  not always so easy to find.

Better than average stock?  Organic meats, fish, dairy, produce and lots of other groceries.  Deli with meats and prepared foods.  On site bakery that turns out bread and desserts.

Staff?  helpful and friendly. lines at the cash register can be very SLOW.

Prices?  Uber-expensive!!!

Bottom Line?  I shop here ONLY when I desperately need something that the older neighborhood liquor/grocery store Buddy's doesn't carry. At Canyon, no matter how little i buy, I always have serious sticker shock at the register.
author: Lisa M.

description: Don't drive. Great bakery, butcher, deli and cheese selection. Long overdue market for Glen Park.
author: lorel j.

description: I don't actually shop here for grocies if I can help it - too pricey, BUT, their sandwiches are so awesome and they have the best specials, I love this place!!  It's my new fave spot for a yummy lunch.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
A bit spendy, but almost everything they specialize in is quite tasty.

They have all kinds of unique spreads and dips and speciality meat items like the (yum!) Canyon burgers you can take home and grill.

This is not the place to buy your months worth of groceries, but if you need something quick or a bit special this place is great.
author: Scott B.

description: This market is NOT great.  Every time I go in there, I expect way better and I'm disappointed.  Products are so over priced it pisses me off.  I would say that the only redeeming features are the fact that you can buy a muni monthly pass here and the bulk salad mix is good quality and a good price.
author: L G.

description:
The looooong anticipated Canyon Market is up and running just steps from the Glen Park BART.  It features a well chosen mix of natural, organic and "regular" items.  Their meat selection is first-rate--Niman Ranch steaks (about $12 a pound) and ribs, hormone-free chicken, etc.  The market shines in its prepared food section-- lots of side dishes like green beans with almonds, mashed potatoes, yummy salads.  Check out their selection of gourmet salad dressings and other similar items.  The salad bar also is first rate.  

The owner, Richard, told me recently that the kinks are still being worked out and that the selection will evolve.  Already, it's not only a most welcome addition to the neighborhood but worth a special trip to grab fresh, wholesome items.
author: Michael D.

description:
The market got off to a slow start: high prices, limited selection and no alcohol for the first week or so. But its clear that the owners have been paying close attention to customer feedback. The prices on some items have already come down, the selection is finally rounded out--including a great selection of fresh vegetables, cheese, and sandwiches--and the overall feel of the market is finally approaching "done".

Canyon Market is a great neighborhood market and now that they are beginning to work out their kinks, its beginning to feel like the neighborhood anchor that all of us locals hoped it would be. The employees are friendly, if a little bit inexperienced, but they will be on the road to making it a great market by the beginning of 2007.

And when the new Italian place opens across the street, Glen Park will finally be able to reclaim its status of being a genuine village destination.
author: Jude M.

description:
Ok, It's a nice new big store in Glen Park....
 NIce stuff, but I can find it all somewhere else and pay half of what I spent there.....$$$$$$$$
The employees look like zombies and look like they despise their job!
Maybe it is a nice addition to the neighborhood but I wasn't pleased...
author: Jane V.

description:
After having given this place several bad reviews, particularly regarding service, I received a reply from Richard, one of the owners, (that doesn't smile).  He responded mainly to the pricing issue and said 'they are working on' better, more efficient service...he offered me a $25 gift card for my trouble and said to just go to the deli where any worker could procure same for me, that he thanked me for giving them a couple of tries.  So today, five days after his email, I went to the deli, where every worker but one was facing away from the customers, and the poor guy who 'helped me' made me wait while he went twice into the back, once around the entire store, including to the front produce area!, then back for third time to the back.  I got tired of still MORE terrible service and left.  The guy caught up with me outside and said there was no gift card and no record of one under the name the owner said to ask about!!!  Par for the course!!
This place is a JOKE.
author: Vernon H.

description: This market has been a welcome upgrade to food choices in Glen Park. It offers a great array of interesting imports, but it's really a high-end deli and convenience store more than a grocery. The higher prices are understandable given the location and the ever-improving preferences of the locals. But the fresh produce selection is sorely limited, and the quality not great. I don't buy any produce I won't use immediately, and frankly prefer to go to other stores with a greater variety that won't turn bad in a day (like their salad greens). I hate to say it, but Safeway presents a better produce section. The cheese selection is sophisticated, and the meat counter a good option. All told, it's a good addition to Glen Park, but not a family-affordable food shopping destination. And one more thing, I can't say I like the kids seeing some of the freaky looking people who work the checkout.
author: Guy Y.

description: fuck canyon market. they can kiss my blackass. them and there overpriced everything. I mean i dont think this review will cause them to lose their ex-hippie/oil investor clientele. ya but im on a boycott of snooty places like  this, whose with me???? if u want phresh stuff, go 2 alemany farmers market.
author: Cole M.

description: With mom and pop markets that cater to city dwellers who want their organic, local produce, it's a given that everything is going to be expensive. That's where your choice of shopping at markets like this, or safeway comes in (and hey, I've got no problem with shopping at safeway). Yeah, Canyon Market is expensive. But they've got some awesome looking deli/prepared food items. The baked goods look great and I definitely want to stop in for a sandwich the next time I'm in town. The egg salad and prosciutto and marinated artichoke and avocado sandwiches sound amazing!
author: Crystal L.

description: cute, small-ish neighborhood grocery store with lots of nice-looking produce and organic healthy foods. they don't have a massive selection, but they have everything you'd need. they also have a deli counter, which i haven't tried. the people who work here are very friendly, they always chat and offer a smile. cute place.
author: Elle B.

description: Good market but avoid the Curry Chicken sandwich
author: thomas M.

description: I'm a fan of their freshly baked french baguettes. Around 4pm, they're warm... :)
author: Tomasz P.

description: this place is painfully overpriced-- you could blow your entire paycheck on a loaf of bread-- BUT it has delicious stuff and A FUCKING AWESOME DELI. the noodles/meatloaf/beans/salads/various other food are so good.  also expensive. but good nonetheless.
author: Samantha G.

description: i'm a driver for recology which is a garbage copany in san francisco . this place is my first stop on the route because the premade food is awsome. the people are frie
author: Luke B.

description: I am really glad this place is close to my house. My usual purchase includes some produce (always fresh and tasty), bottle of wine (or 3), fresh meat or fish. All the stuff at the deli counter is really good. Soups are good. I've had people feed me with cheese and information while wandering around there. The spreads section on the left when you head toward the check out line, has all kinds of good stuff. Spicy hummus, pico de gallo, cheese spread, mole, bring it.
author: Sean S.

description:
High end market with a good selection of high end produce. Cheaper than Molly Stone's, but better service. Great wines.
The neighborhood went to great lengths to stop the market and some of the resentment is still visible, but this market with fresh, mostly organic, carefully picked produce and products costs what any business which pays fair wages and takes pains has to charge to meet a bottom line.
All of the bread and pastries are house made, the deli and cheese selections are exceptional and the salad bar offers delicious house made soups (I found myself in a fight with a man who wanted the last of the tortilla soup one night). The wines, the oils and the various delicacies are hand selected by the owner, whose wife, a pastry chef, is responsible for the great selection of fresh bread and some of the pastries. 
The take grab and go items at the counter are reasonable and delicious. I often pick a few things up when I visit friends in places like Stockton, so I don't have to eat in the local restaurants. The market offers a number of vegetarian and vegan items, all of which are more than acceptable to omnivores. 
For those who find it too expensive, there's Safeway's mediocre but cheap food on Monterey or up the hill and a couple of by the book corner groceries in the neighborhood. 
You can have cheap, and you can have good, but they rarely go together. Canyon is a terrific resource. 
By the way, the owner does smile. He's just really, really serious and earnest about food.
author: Otto S.

description:
the sandwiches are the best in the city & almost a tad underpriced.
yes, the other grocery stuff is pricier than safeway, but canyon market is a very different place  from safeway- they have better produce, fresh bread, wider selection and it's a beautiful space.  the owners are not making a killing on this - far from it.  but it takes a lot of $ to run a place like that & people should understand that.
author: Kim Y.

description: ok place, cafe, good to meet folks, but not that diverise products and overpriced
author: Leigh McInnis Lee G.

description: Great selection of cheeses. The breads were delicious too!  It has a really nice selection of beer and wine and well as a good list of organic fruits and veggies. The salad bar is fabulous too!
author: Krishawna F.

description: I haven't really shopped here much (coffee sometimes, and Muni pass) but I thought it was a cool little shop. But when they refuse to sell the Mission YMCA Bart tickets, I will NEVER buy anything from them ever again!!! My brother's son goes to the Y Camp, and they we going to an art museum in Oakland, and Bart didn't accept their card. So Bart told them that they can go to the Canyon Market and that they should be able to sell them to her. Well when the director walked over there to buy them, the manager himself refused to sell her them. He stated that he was saving them for his "community", when the YMCA severs children in the Glen Park area which is his community! My nephew child lives in Glen Park!!! Due to his cold heartedness the staff was forced to change their trip to the art museum (which they were charged $40 for canceling lost minute) and they had to take the children to the park. I can't believe this man, and that he can say no to such a good spirit group of people who help keep children off the streets for the summer. A group of parents at the Y are boycotting this store and I would like you all to do the same.
author: Vincent H.

description: I visited this market for the first time and I think it will be my last time. Although it looks nice, I was disappointed to find that the prices were so HIGH. I mean, I spent about $60 on different things--I would have come far ahead had I driven to Rainbow Grocery. I felt like I had walked into this alternate universe where everything was about 20-30% more expensive than the norm at other comparable stores in the city. I did not even leave the store with a full bag or even 2 meals. They would be better off to offer people some "special offers" and/or lowering their prices (like Rainbow Grocery). I had one of the prepared foods from the deli and it was really dry and had no flavor. Maybe the people in Glen Park have the income to pay so much for a few groceries, but for the rest of us, a good value vs. good price balance could be better reached.  I know it must be expensive to run such a store, but just seems like they could do a much better business for more people if their products were not so out of reach for most people.
author: Don P.

description: For what it is, this is a nice corner grocery store. A little bit of everything, but not much of each thing. They have worked well with the space and carry high-end items. It is not a place to shop for people on a tight budget, but it is great in a pinch. The 8 o'clock closing time can be frustrating.
author: Suzanne H.

description: Their seasonal fruit is great.  People who complain...well it's SEASONAL.  White french baguettes though expensive were the best.  Preferable to Acme or Semifreddi.  They had a baker problem and I am waiting to see if the baguettes have recovered.  Good pre-prepared food.  Try their hazlenut torte.
author: Christine N.

description:
this place is a disaster.  what a disappoint to have waited so long for a small local grocer and find this.  

i visited yesterday which is about a month after their grand opening.  i had heard it got off to a rocky opening.  so i waited.  even well established grocerers have challenges with keeping stock and personnel up to snuff during holidays.  

so i expected to find things in order and up and running smoothly by this week.

wow.  stock was definitely out of balance in the produce and other depts.  the displays were a haphazard mess and downright ugly.  i was bending and reaching over an empty steel bin on the floor in front of the apples I was attempting to gather.  there were lots of other wine crates and half filled baskets placed on the floor right in front of cold product case.  strange.

another example is that the tortillas were not near the bread or anything else that made sense.  they were on a little wire rack/tower at the end of the cold produce case, and sort of stuck in a corner behind something else.

i was shopping with a list.  but had to skip the purchase of paper towels.  i don't mind paying a little extra for the convenience of very local shopping, environmentally-sensitive products, short lines, etc.  but $3.49 for one -- skimpy -- roll of paper towels is absurd.  i can get them delivered to my door step from the most expensive retailer for less than that!

then the real shake-up was when i wanted to purchase a loaf of ciabatta.  i could not find the bags.  asked the clerk who took a used, crumpled up bag (and too small of a bad for my loaf) off the counter and handed me the loaf.  when i asked what bakery provided the bread, he didn't know.

by the time i got to the meat/seafood dept, I was too full of disappoint to even look let alone make a purchase.  and there was no one around to help anyway.

the only thing that was straight forward and without fraught was the purchase of a fresh head of romaine lettuce at 99 cents.

for couple of other price examples from my receipt:

med size bottle of tamari (soy) sauce = $4.79
organic bananas at .99/lb [that's competitive pricing with rainbow]

i left with two very light bags and the bill was $39


this place will never make it without some major management improvements, pricing improvements, and display styling.

to me it's an embarrassment to the neighborhood.

SF resident for 15 years.
author: Carlin D.

description: I am in love with Canyon Market! Their prepared food is fantastic, they have an amazing selection of organics and specialty items.  Their sandwiches are truly the best I have ever had.  It has become my regular stop for lunch.  I pick up a sandwich and I inevitably leave with a pizza as well.  Their homemade chocolate mousse is to die for. I can't say enough nice things about this very sweet and friendly delicious neighborhood market.
author: Lorena N.

description: Nice - small version of Whole Foods - pricey though!
author: John S.

description: I LOVE Canyon Market for so many reasons. I love it because they have three (fresh) great soups each and every day, including Vegetable Minestrone, Clam Chowder, Sausage and Bean, Meatball and Rice, Turkey Pasta, Chicken Tortilla, Broccoli cheddar, 7 seas fish, butternut squash. I could go on an on. A sweet little roll --(whole wheat sesame or sour dough) right next to go with. OR A salad bar filled with delectable choices, all of the regular stuff but including red/golden beets, various housemade  salads  including potato, roasted vegetables, couscous, rice blends, roasted corn and tomatoes, plus  great homemade dressings topped off with  a diverse olive bar . A well staffed deli section with delectable (might take a few minutes) custom sandwiches, and at least 20 different salads/and other deli choices ( ALL of which all that I have tried are delectable --love Pad Thai)  A great meat section where  you can buy a full roasted chicken or  walk down  (as we do) and pick out a great cut of something for a Saturday night BBQ.  Check out the on site (often warm when you buy it) made bread, sour and baguettes and everything in between, as well as cupcakes or cheese cake (even vegan varieties) or rare chocolate all up in front. Also the produce section is filled with in season fruits and vegetables with choices galore! PLUS Canyon Market has seasonal flowers and plants, a coffee bar and an eclectic wine department. Prices are reasonable for what you get. A truly great neighborhood market that makes Glen Park proud!
author: Lewiston S.

description: I am absoultely fed up with this place. Eveytime I go there I leave promising myself to never go back. Today was the ultimate last time! I enter go to buy some produce and meat...hmmm only 1 cabbage that isn't even fresh looking - fine let me just get the meat at this point - I go up to the butcher counter andask the lady for some help - she's fixing the scale turns around and starts gossiping with another female employee and doesn't even acknowledge me event though I'm right in her face. I ask the other lady for help - all I want is some dame lamb chili grinded - she tells me she needs to ask the butcher if he can do it that is if he has the time - I say fine and wait about 10 minutes to get my answer - she comes back helps another customer and then comes to me with an answer - the butcher says you need to buy at least 2 pounds - I say fine - she sighs and I ask her to please tell him I still want it - then this punk kid comes out from the back (this is the butcher) and starts telling me about how he would have to turn on the grinder and how its such an inconvenience and how I need to buy 2 punds before he would actually do it but he would only be able to give me 1.5 pounds b/c the grinder looses half a pound when you actually grind meat. After his bullshit attitude I decided to leave the basket I had filled with less than mediocre produce in the middle of the store and walk out. So to Canyon Market I say : FUCK YOU AND ALL THE BITCHES WHO WORK THERE! I live right up the street and I am never going back - today I decided I will continue to give Mollie Stones my business because you don't deserve it. If I could give no stars I would but this website won't let me. This place is an embarassment to Glen Park and the people who run it and work there have no damn clue what they are doing - go get some experience before you decide to run a wannabe Whole Foods!
author: SF Gal ..
